loans.name: Ni Komang Taman

texts.id:
Ni Komang Taman is in the business of trading coconut leaves to support the family income as her husband only works as a farmer. Ni Komang is a mother of a son.

With loan money, she buys coconut leaves and re-sells them to customers. Coconut leaves is one of the articles required for routine religius activities in Bali.

She buys the coconut leaves from her neighbors for IDR 5 thousand (around USD 0.55) and re-sells them for IDR 10 thousand (USD 1.1). In a week she can earn up to IDR 100,000 (USD 11) as profit. This extra income is cruicial in supporting her family daily needs. She hopes she can expand her business in the future.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Ni Komang Taman saat ini menjalankan usaha jual beli janur karena suaminya hanya bekerja sebagai seorang petani. Dalam pernikahan mereka, Ni Komang Taman di karuniai 1 orang anak laki-laki. Untuk itu Ni Komang Taman tidak bisa hanya mengandalkan penghasilan suami saja dalam memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya karena hasil bertani tidak menentu. Dengan modal pinjaman yang didapat Ni Komang Taman membeli janur atau pelepah kelapa untuk dijual kembali. Usaha ini dijalankan sejak Ni Komang Taman menikah. Janur dan pelepah dibeli dari warga sekitarnya. Satu pelepah dibeli Rp.5000.- dan dijual kembali dengan harga Rp.10.000.- Keuntungan yang diterima dalam satu minggu Rp.100.000.- Suaminya juga ikut membantu dalam usaha ini. Keuntungan yang diterima sangat membantu dalam memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya. Ni Komang Taman berharap untuk kedepannya agar usahanya bisa maju, sehingga bisa menopang kebutuhan keluarganya.

loans.use: To add working capital (Menambah modal usaha untuk membeli lebih banyak janur)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Porpeal Khe Group

texts.en: This is a group loan that will be shared between 28 members of the Porpeal Khe Village Bank in Kandal Province. Mrs. Yol C., 44, is a farmer and also the Village Bank President. She is married with five children, all of whom are students and do not make money. Their parents can make around $7 to $9 per day. Mrs. C. requests this loan  of $3625 to buy more vegetables to sell everyday.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: I Gusti Ayu Kurniati

texts.id:
I Gusti Ayu Putu Kurniati and her husband have a two year old boy named I Gusti Aria Oka. This young couple is very hard working. I Gusti Ayu Putu Kurniati's husband works as a security guard for a private company. As soon as Gusti Kurniati heard about the opportunity to receive a business loan to grow her pig farming business, she applied for a loan of 5,000,000 Rupiah. In her business she has raised 10 fattened pigs. 2,500,000 Rupiah of the loan would be used to purchase a boar. The pig pen she uses is not permanent. It is made of bamboo with a roof made of palm leaves. and is not a good place to raise young pigs. Every day Gusti Kurniati is very busy with all of the work involved in raising her pigs from cleaning their pen to bringing them food. She says the target age for fattening and selling her pigs is four months. She estimates that it costs her 5,000,000 Rupiah to feed and care for a pig until it is 4 months old and ready to sell. Unfortunately, the cost of pig feed has gone up. She makes approximately 10,000,000 selling a pig and after paying for a boar and the pig feed she has about 2,500,000 every 4 months. From this money she plans to build a permanent pig pen.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

I Gusti Ayu Putu Kurniati dan suaminya baru memiliki 1 orang anak laki-laki yang diberi nama I Gusti Aria Oka umur 2 tahun. Pasangan muda yang baru membina sebuah keluarga ini bisa dibilang pekerja yang ulet. Suaminya bekerja sebagai satpam disebuah perusahaan swasta. Mendengar ada pinjaman dana dari Dinari yang ditujukan untuk usaha, Gusti Kurniati langsung bergabung dan mendapat pinjaman dana sebesar Rp.5.000.000,-. Gusti Kurniati memelihara 10 ekor babi penggemukan. Modal awal untuk bibit menghabiskan Rp.2.500.000.- Walaupun kandangnya tidak permanen, hanya dipagari oleh bambu dan atapnya ditutupi oleh daun kelapa, tidak mengurangi semangat Gusti Kurniati untuk memelihara penggemukan. Setiap hari Gusti Kurniati disibukan dengan mengurus babinya dari mulai membersihkan kandang sampai memberi makan. Gusti Kurniati memiliki target umur 4 bulan harus dijual dengan berat maksimal. Sampai umur 4 bulan biaya pakan diperkirakan akan menghabiskan Rp.5.000.000,- karena saat ini semua biaya pakan naik. Pendapatan kotor dari penjualan babinya Rp.10.000.000,-. Setelah dipotong biaya bibit dan pakan keuntungan bersihnya Rp.2.500.000.,- per 4 bulan. Dari hasil inilah Gusti Kurniati akan berencana bertahap memperbaiki kandangnya supaya permanen.

loans.use: to purchase a quality boar and pig feed

loans.name: Ni Komang Sri Virgaw

texts.id:
Komang Sri Virgawati has worked for five years selling incense for use in Balainese Hindu rituals. She sells her incense by traveling around everywhere from her home village of Pangkung Liplip to the village of Melaya. She would like to get a loan of 5,000,000 Rupiah to purchase additional incense to sell. She buys the incense from a bigger merchant in the city. incense comes in variety packs costing 5,000 or 6,000 Rupiah depending on the type. She makes approximately 500,000 Rupiah per day selling incense. After all of her business expenses including transportation, she brings home between 50,000 and 60,000 Rupiah per day. Sri Virgawati has two children, one of which is already in primary school and the other is still a baby. Her husband works as a repair man at a bicycle shop and brings home approximately 500,000 per month. They use his income to purchase a new motor for the motorcycle she uses in her business. Her income is used to pay for their everyday living expenses and to care for her children. She would like to get a loan to help increase her business profits and better help her family.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Komang Sri Virgawati sudah hampir 5 tahun menjadi Pedagang Dupa ( Alat sembahyang Umat Hindu). Sri Virgawati menjual dupa berkeliling dari rumahnya Pangkung Liplip sampai di Desa Melaya. Sri Virgawati mendapat tambahan modal usaha dari Dinari sebesar Rp. 5.000.000.- Sri Virgawati membeli dupa dari pedagang besar dikotanya. Harga 1 dupa bermacam-macam, ada yang 1 bungkus harganya Rp. 5.000.- dan ada yang Rp. 6.000.- Setiap hari penghasilan kotor yang diterima oleh Sri Virgawati sebesar Rp. 500.000.- Sedangkan keuntungan bersih yang diterima perhari setelah dipotong biaya transportasi mencapai Rp. 50.000.- sd Rp. 60.000.- Sri Virgawati memiliki 2 orang anak yang satu sudah bersekolah di SD, dan yang nomor 2 masih balita. Suami Sri Virgawati pekerjaannya sebagai montir di bengkel sepeda di desanya dengan penghasilan perbulan Rp. 500.000.- Penghasilan suaminya dipakai untuk membayar cicilan sepeda motornya sedangkan penghasilan Sri Virgawati untuk biaya sehari - hari dan uang jajan anaknya. Karena itulah Sri Virgawati sangat bersyukur mendapat pinjaman dana dari Dinari.

loans.use: to increase her business capitol so she can purchase more incense

loans.name: Thi Xuan

texts.vi:
Mrs Xuân is 38 years old. She has 2 young children. Selling waste metal and raising poultry are the main source of income for her family. She makes between 50000-70000 VND a day (~3.15-4.40 USD). She has borrowed from lenders before and she nad repaid. She likes SEDA loan condition plus she can make weekly payment and it does not require collateral. She is requesting a loan of 200600 VND to have capital to buy waste metal.

Translated by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Xuân, 38 tuổi, có 2 con nhỏ còn đang đi học. Đi chợ sắt vụn và chăn nuôi gà là hai nghề chính tạo thu nhập cho gia đình chị. Thu nhập trung bình của cả nhà cũng được 50000-70000 đồng/ngày. Chị đã từng vay ở ngoài và đã trả hết. Chị thích vay ở Chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc hơn vì được trả góp và không phải thế chấp, nên chị đã vay 2006000 đồng để thêm vốn đi chợ.

loans.use: buy waste metal

loans.name: Ni Komang Maria Coa

texts.id:
Ni Komang Maria Coa and her husband use to live in Timor-Timur (East Timur) because her husband was in the military. Because of the conflict there, their family moved to the area of Banjar Pangkung Liplip in the village of Kaliakah in Western Bali, where her husband was born. Maria Coa and her husband have three children. To help keep her family going she opened a general store at their house using 5,000,000 Rupiah that her husband gave her. At her store she sells vegetables, various snacks, rolls, rice, soft drinks and kerosene. She travels to the market in the city to purchase the goods she sells in her store. She must spend as much as 200,000 Rupiah per day to purchase her goods and she makes at most 300,000 Rupiah per day in profits. She is usually left with about 50.0000 Rupiah (after putting money back into her business) which she uses to pay for her family's daily needs. Her husband's income is used to pay for her children's education. Recently the cost of the goods she buys at the market have gone up and the original funding she used is not enough to cover costs. Maria Coa would like to obtain a loan to help keep her business going and to grow it further.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Ni Komang Maria Coa dan suami sebelumnya tinggal di Timor-Timur karena suaminya sebagai seorang tentara. Karena konflik yang terjadi disana, akhirnya mereka memutuskan untuk pulang kembali ke Bali tepatnya di tanah kelahiran suaminya Banjar Pangkung Liplip Desa kaliakah, Bali Barat. Maria Coa memiliki 3 orang anak. Untuk memenuhi semua kebutuhan rumah tangganya Maria Coa membuka usaha Warung di rumahnya dengan modal usaha dari suaminya sebesar Rp. 5.000.000.- Adapun dagangan yang dijual diwarungnya seperti: sayur-sayuran, lauk-pauk, berbagai macam makanan ringan, roti, beras, berbagai macam minuman dan minyak tanah. Semua keperluan dagangannya dibeli di pasar pagi dikotanya. Setiap hari Maria Coa mengeluarkan modal untuk berbelanja sebesar Rp. 200.000.-Sedangkan pendapatan kotornya setiap hari mencapai Rp. 300.000.-. Dengan keuntungan setiap hari Rp. 50.000.- Dengan keuntungan inilah Maria Coa bisa membantu pengeluaran rumah tangganya. Sedangkan penghasilan suaminya dipakai untuk biaya pendidikan anak-anaknya. Maria Coa merasa bahwa saat ini harga barang semua naik dan modal yang diputar sudah tidak cukup. Untuk itulah Maria Coa bergabung didalam kelompok ini untuk mendapatkan bantuan Modal usaha dari Dinari agar usahanya bisa tetap berjalan dan menjadi berkembang.

loans.use: to increase capitol for her business

loans.name: Ni Made Mey Arianti

texts.id:
Mey Arianti is a very hardworking housewife. She opened a general store at her home. Even though her store is very basic, her store is never empty of visitors. Mey Arianti's husband takes her to the local market every morning to purchase goods to sell in her store. The items she sells include vegetables, rice, coconut oil, kerosene and various snacks and soft drinks. She works very hard and puts lots of energy into making her business a success. Although she gets very tired from all of her hard work, she never complains! She must spend Rp. 200,000 (USD $22) per day to run her store, while her daily gross profit varies from Rp 300,000 (USD $33) to Rp 500,000 (USD $55). This leaves her with a net profit of around Rp 30,000 (USD $3.30) to Rp 60,000 (USD $6.60) per day. With this small income, she pays for her two children to attend primary school. Her husband's income is also very low because he works as a farm laborer on another person's farm. For all of his hard work he only gets paid after the crops are harvested and sold, and then he must split the profits. Mey Arianti would like a loan to help her business so she can better help her family.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Vincent Liew & Courtenay Teska Race

Mey Arianti adalah seorang ibu yang sangat tekun bekerja. Saat ini Mey arianti sedang membuka uasaha warung dirumahnya. Walaupun warungnya sangat sederhana, tetapi setiap hari tidak pernah sepi dari para pengunjung. Mey Arianti membeli dagangan di pasar pagi di kotanya diantar oleh suaminya. Adapun yang dijual diwarungnya lauk-pauk, sayur-mayur, beras, minyak kelapa, minyak tanah, berbagai macam makanan ringan dan minuman. Mey Arianti sangat tekun dan bersemangat dalam menekuni usahanya. Walaupun sangat melelahkan tetapi Mey Arianti tidak pernah mengeluh. Modal yang dikeluarkan setiap hari untuk modal warungnya sekitar Rp. 200.000.- Sedangkan penghasilan kotor perhari Rp. 300.000.-sd Rp. 500.000.- Keuntungan bersih yang diterima oleh Mey Arianti Rp. 30.000.- sd Rp. 60.000.- Dari penghasilan inilah Mey Arianti bisa menyekolahkan 2 anaknya yang sekarang masih duduk di bangku SD. Penghasilan suaminya tidak banyak , karena suaminya mengerjakan sawah orang lain dengan sistem bagi hasil dari keuntungannya di bagi 2 dan baru dapat uang setelah panen. Mey Arianti bersyukur mendapat pinjaman dari Dinari karena ini sangat berarti bagi usahanya.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell at her General Store

loans.name: Thi Hoan

texts.vi:
Mrs Hoàn is 33. She has 2 young children who are in school. Her main occupation is selling basic goods and fish. Her family income is 50000-70000 VND a day (3.15-4.40 USD). She has never borrowed money before because it is collateral is required. Now that she knows about SEDA, she has applied for a loan of 2006000 VND to buy merchandise to resell. She likes the idea of paying back the loan in installments.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Hoàn, 33 tuổi, có hai con nhỏ đang còn đi học. Chị làm nghề đi chợ sắt vụn và bán cá. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị là 50000-70000 đồng/ngày. Chị chưa từng vay ở đâu cả vì phải thế chấp. Chị lại rất muốn vay vốn để đi chợ sắt vụn, vì vậy chị tham gia chương trùnh tài chính vi mô bình minh cdc với mức vay 2006000 đồng vì không phải thế chấp lại trả góp hàng tuần với số tiền nhỏ.

loans.use: buy merchandise to resell

loans.name: Thi Tam

texts.vi:
Ms. Tam, 48 years old, has never known where to get a loan because she is not yet confident that she would be able to repay such a loan. Now that Ms. Tam has learned about Binhminh CDC (Kiva Partner in Vietnam), she thinks it is reasonable for her to borrow a small loan of 150 USD to help her start collecting recyclables during her time when she is not at work (for her main job). She hopes this woud increase her family income significantly. She gains more confidence because her son is now grown up enough to help her somehow. With the daily income of 5USD, her family now can barely make ends meet.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Tám, 48 tuổi, từ trước đến nay chưa biết vay vốn ở đâu vì chị chưa tự tin với mức trả cả khoản lớn. Trong khi chị chỉ đi làm mướn nuôi cả gia đình với những khoản thu nhập nhỏ lẻ thì chị thấy tham gia với chương trình tài chính binhminh cdc là rất hợp lý để đi chợ đồng nát tạo thu nhập thành một món lớn cho bản thân. Chị đã tự tin hơn khi có một cậu con trai đã đi làm giúp chị phần nào. Với mức thu nhập 80000đồng/ngày, cả gia đình chị có thể đủ ăn.

loans.use: To collect recyclables

loans.name: Thi Duong

texts.vi: Mrs. Dương, who is 35 years old, successfully turned her first loan into a thriving fish farm, in addition to her raising of ducks and pigs. She currently makes her money by selling duck eggs and fish at the local market. Mrs. Dương prefers Kiva's weekly repayment system because it allows her with her extra money to buy more feed for the animals. She now earns $6.35 USD a day. | Chị Dương, 35 tuổi, đã vay vốn của ngân hàng để thầu ao thả cá, đồng thời gia đình chị còn chăn nuôi vịt và lợn. Để có thu nhập hàng ngày, chị đã phải đi lấy trứng và cá bán lấy lãi, chị thấy trả tiền hàng tuần rất thích hợp với số tiền kiếm được 100000đồng/ngày mà lại có một khoản lớn để mua thức ăn cho cá, vịt, lợn nên chị đã đăng ký và tham gia vào chương trình.

loans.use: Farming animals | Chăn nuôi thả cá

loans.name: Ear

texts.en: Mrs. Ear C., 42, works selling clothes in the market with her daughter, making on average about $10 per day. Her husband contributes to the family income by operating a service cleaning motorbikes and cars at home, earning about $5 a day. They have five children, two of whom are married and living away from home. To expand her business and meet customer demand, she requests a loan of $200 for the purchase of additional clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Le Giang

texts.vi: Mrs. Giang, who is 28 years old, would like T. obtain a $150 Kiva loan T. expand her small street vending business. She likes the Kiva business model of providing microcredit T. people like herself. Mrs. Giang promises T. be a good Kiva business partner. She earns approximately $4.50 USD a day. | Chị Giang, 28 tuổi, vay vốn về để bổ sung cho việc bán hàng tăng thêm mức thu nhập hàng ngày cho gia đình chị. Với thủ tục đơn giản, dễ tiếp cận là những ưu điểm của chương trình tài chính binhminh cdc nên chị đã vay 2006000 đồng. Và chị tin sẽ trả tốt và tham gia thường xuyên với chương trình với mức thu nhập nhỏ lẻ 70000đồng/ngày/

loans.use: Street vending | Bán hàng ăn

loans.name: Lan

texts.en: Mrs. Lan P., 59, has a business milling rice with her husband for the local farmers, using their rice grinding mill to remove the husks from the rice. They have seven children, six of whom are married and living independently. She is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva to breed pigs to develop an additional income.

loans.use: To breed pigs.

loans.name: Thi Bich's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Bích, who is 44 years old, and her husband, Mr. Đức, are very creative and innovative with their current recycling business. They buy used plastic containers and melt them into a block for recycling. She initially borrowed money from a bank geared towards women to start her first business. Mrs. Bích needs to have a large capital investment for her next venture. Mrs. Bích is attracted to Kiva's loans because of the simple process and the ability to repay in installments. She wants to use the loan to start a rice processing business. Mrs. Bích's son also contributes to their business and the family earns an average of $8.25 USD a day. | Chị Bích, 44 tuổi và anh Đức, chồng chị rất năng động. Hai anh chị mua đồ nhựa bị loại bỏ về sàng lọc và tái chế lại. Nghề của anh chị cần rất nhiều vốn, Chị đã vay của ngân hàng vốn phụ nữ. Nhưng anh chị vẫn thích tham gia của chương trình tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì được trả dần. Ngoài thu nhập của anh chị thì một con đã đi làm tạo thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Mức thu nhập của cả gia đình cũng được khoảng 130000 đồng/ngày.
Chị Đức thì mong muốn vay vốn để mua thêm gạo xay xát rồi bán.

loans.use: Plastic recycling & rice processing businesses | Sản xuất nhựa và xay xát gạo

loans.name: Loun

texts.en: Mrs. Loun S., 58, (her husband is pictured) is a housewife with two children, one who is married and living away from home and another who is a construction laborer earning $2 a day and living at home.  Her husband works as a carpenter and earns $2.50 a day.  In order to reduce costs, this couple is asking for a loan of $600 from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Loun Sarom start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Mr. Pen C., 54, is a widower with 3 children who works in construction in Siem Reap Province. He  normally earns about $4 a day. To save on commuting expenses, he is requesting a loan of $300 from Kiva to purchase a motorbike. In the future when he has enough capital, he will open a small business for his children selling grocery products. He thanks you for your consideration.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: Mrs. Sin T., 37, a mother of five children, has a business selling a variety of vegetables in the market, earning about $6 a day. Her husband works as a motor-taxi driver and makes on average $4 of profit per day.  She requests a loan of $1000 from Kiva to rent a market stand, which will enable her to significantly expand her vegetable sales. This will provide greater income to help improve the family’s living conditions.

loans.use: To rent a market stand.

loans.name: Sroun

texts.en: Mrs. Sroun H., 39, a mother of six children, works selling a variety of vegetables in the market close to her house, earning about $5 a day. Her husband contributes to the family income as a construction worker building houses, on average earning about $4 a day. Two of their sons also work at the construction site, normally earning around $3 each per day. Mrs. H. requests a loan of $200 to purchase more grocery products to sell, as she now has many customers.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Mrs. Seng S., 26 (her husband is pictured), the mother of one child, has a business selling grocery products from her house, usually earning about $3 a day. Her husband, Mr. Chan Chen, 27, works as a truck driver with a revenue of $10 a day. To improve their standard of living and increase income, they request a loan of $1000 from Kiva which, along with savings, will enable them to purchase a small truck for Mr. Chen to transport  sand from the river to the construction site.

loans.use: To purchase a small truck.

loans.name: Teak

texts.en: Mrs. Teak S., 20, married with 2 children, operates a business selling souvenirs near Bayon Temple, earning on average $5 a day of profit. Her husband works making drums to sell in the market, earning around $7 a day. She would like to borrow $200 from Kiva to purchase more Khmer-made souvenirs, created by poor people in Siem Reap Province, to sell to the tourists visiting Angkor Wat.  (Mrs. Teak S. was not available for the picture.)

loans.use: To purchase more souvenirs for resale.

loans.name: Ashmatallah

texts.en: Ashmatallah lives in district 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is the father of two children. He has a retail shop. He started this business one year ago. During this time, his business has been normal. Now he wants to expand his business, so he requested an individual loan to complete his stock. He wants to make a good income to help his family. He is happy with this loan process that helps poor people around Afghanistan.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Identity

texts.en: The entrepreneur is 29 years old. He has two children, and one of them was born 8 months ago. He is living in a rented house and has a barbershop in Kirkuk. He applied to borrow $1200 to purchase new furniture and mirrors and paint the shop. He wants to make some advertising in order to expand his project and increase his income and improve himself.

loans.use: Purchase new furniture and mirrors.

loans.name: Violeth's Kota Group

texts.en:
Violeth is 32 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 5 and 1 year old. Violeth owns a small stock of animals, which she started in 2003. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

In the past, Violeth has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more feed for her animals. She will share this loan with her subgroup member,Salma, who has a business dealing in chickens.

loans.use: To buy more food for her animals

loans.name: Ngeav

texts.en: Mrs. Ngeav M. is a mother of five children who, with her husband, works breeding pigs, making on average $2 a day. To increase the family’s income they request a loan of $600 from Kiva to purchase more pigs to breed.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to breed.

loans.name: Mwanahamisi

texts.en:
Mwanahamisi is 28 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 8, 5, and 3 years old. Mwanahamisi is a cloth seller, a business she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

In the past,Mwanahamisi has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more cothes for her business.

loans.name: Abduaziz

texts.ru:
Abduaziz T. is a 35 year old man, who is married and has three children. His wife stays at home. Abduaziz has a workshop, where he produces wooden utencils and other kitchen tools such as rolling-pin and bolten. He has been in this business for the last 10 years. Currently, he employs his brother as a helper. After production, he sells his products in bulk to individual sellers on a market, where there is a large demand for his products. Abduaziz is asking for a loan, so he could purchase raw materials, namely wood, for his business.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

Таджибаев Абдуазиз мужчина в возросте 35 лет имеет 3 детей , жена домохозяйка.Абдуазиз на дому имеет цех по производству деревянных приборов по дому, для кухни скалка для теста, толчанка,сито.Уже 10 лет как он занимается этим бизненсом.Сейчас у него в цеху работает брат помощником.После изготовления он оптом здает товар на базаре.Его товар пользуется большим спросом. Абдуазиз хочет закупить материал для производства,древесину,для чего обратился в Микроинвест.

loans.use: Production of wooden tools

loans.name: Arafa's Mkombozi Group

texts.en:
Arafa is 32 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages12, 7, and 3 years old. Arafa owns a small food store, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $85 from her sales.

In the past, Arafa has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in retail shops and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Nabat

texts.en: Nabat was born in 1960. She is single, and lives in the Khachmaz region. Nabat and her brother (who is pictured) have raised cattle for 6 years. They need a loan of $1200 to buy a cow.

loans.use: to buy  a cow

loans.name: Maimuna's Mbuyuni Group

texts.en:
Maimuna is 22 years old and is a single woman. Maimuna owns a small shop, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 7am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

In the past, Maimuna has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in "bites"-selling, cloth, and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Kiwalazi East C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Florence N.. She is currently in the business of selling fish and is requesting a loan to purchase more fish in bulk. Florence is 32 years old and is married. She has 6 children ranging from age 2 to 15 and her children go to school. Each week, Florence makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house and also educate her children.

Florence is joined in her small group by Rose A., Justine W., Christine A., and Taaka L.. Rose A. has a business selling charcoal and wants to boost business. Justine W. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to purchase more shop items. Christine A. operates a restaurant business and wants to add furniture and utensils. Taaka L. is currently in the business of selling matooke and is requesting a loan to add to her business.

loans.use: To expand fish selling business and make more profits

loans.name: Leticia's Furaha. Group

texts.en:
Leticia is 30 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 7 and 4 years old. Leticia is a vegetable seller, a business she started in 2005. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

In the past, Leticia has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in banana selling, alcohol selling, food vending, vegetables, and charcoal selling.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Eldar

texts.en: Eldar was born in 1961. He is married and has 3 children. He has run a general store for 4 years. Now he needs a loan of  $950 to buy  goods for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy goods

loans.name: Kiwalazi East D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Joyce N.. She is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and is requesting a loan to add more capital. Joyce is 28 years old and is married. She has 6 children ranging from age 3 to 10 and her children go to school. Each week, Joyce makes approximately UGX 6000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in her business.

Joyce is joined in her small group by Rose N., Edodo G., Scovia N., and Annet B.. Rose N. has a business selling matooke and wants to increase her sales. Edodo G. is currently operating a business selling fish and wants a loan to increase her inventory. Scovia N. operates a retail shop business and wants to add more stock. Annet B. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to uplift business.

loans.use: To add capital to tomato business and boost it

loans.name: Sheha's Mji Mwema Group

texts.en:
Sheha is 32 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 14, 11, and 4 years old. Sheha is a tailor, a business she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business.

In the past, Sheha has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in cloth selling, pharmacy, and soft drink selling.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu is 48 years old and is a married woman. Tatu owns a small charcoal store, which she started in 2005. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

In the past, Tatu has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a second loan to buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business

loans.name: Elnara

texts.en: Elnara (her husband is pictured) is a mother of 2 children. Her husband has been in the taxi business for 3 years. The Gandjaliyev family lives in Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. Now, they need a loan of $850 to buy the spare parts for improving their business.

loans.use: to buy the spare parts for his taxi

loans.name: Theresia's Mkombozi Group

texts.en:
Theresia is 50 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 24, 21, 18, and 16 years old. Theresia is a food and vegetable seller, a business she started in 2003. Every day, she works from 6am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

In the past, Theresia has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Sharifa, who has a business dealing in retail sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Mayis

texts.en: This young man is single. He was born in 1983. Mayis has sold phone accessories for 2 years. He lives in the town of Khachmaz. He needs a loan of $950 to buy phone accessories for improving his business.

loans.use: to buy phone accessories

loans.name: Asha's Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman with 4 children, ages15, 12, 9, and 5 years old. Asha owns a small food store, which she started in 2005. Every day, she works from 9am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in food vending and soft drink selling.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith, age 55, owns five Friesian cows and five calves whose milk she sells to retail customers. Currently, only two of her cows are producing milk, giving her 80 liters of milk each week. She employs three full-time workers who cut grass, milk the cows and help maintain the property. Faith has had this business for eight years.

Faith is a widow who lives with and supports her three children, six grandchildren and the three children of her late brother who died of AIDS.

There is sufficient space for up to 30 cows on Faith’s property and her aim is to be able to grow her business to this size.

loans.use: Faith is asking for a loan to purchase feed and pharmaceuticals for her ten cows.

loans.name: Stella's Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Stella is a single woman with 4 children, ages 22, 13, 8, and 2 and a half years old. She also takes care of 3 other people, ages 50, 40, and 25 years old. Stella owns a small grocery store, which she started in 1997. Every day, she works from 6am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Isabela, who has a little cafe.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Barry

texts.en:
Barry is 28 years old and is an extremely hard working man who is looking for a loan to allow him to increase and improve the inventory of his store to enable him to provide a better life for his wife and four children. He has been running his store for 10 years, since the birth of his first child. His wife and their eldest child work with Barry in the store. All four of his children go to school.

Barry runs two other businesses as well as his general store. He owns four Friesian cows, selling their milk to retailers. He also owns a motorcycle, which he rents to a local man to use as a taxi service.

Barry hopes to be able to afford to buy a new cow to aid his milk production and eventually buy another motorcycle to add to his taxi business.

loans.use: Barry intends to use the loan to purchase additional sugar, salt, cooking oil for his general store.

loans.name: Cristina's Raia Mwema. Group

texts.en:
Cristina is a married woman with 5 children, ages 23, 20, 17, 13, and 9 years old. Cristina owns a small food store, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 3pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in tailoring, groceries, retail shop, and charcoal selling.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Rauf

texts.en: Rauf is 24 years old, and lives in Khachmaz.  He would like a loan of $950 to further his business of selling foodstuffs and supplying produce to his village.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Tiba's Raia Mwema Group

texts.en:
Tiba is a married woman with 3 children, ages 18, 15 ,and 12 years old. Tiba owns a small food store, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Benadeta, who has a little cafe.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry is 35 years old and has been running his shop for two years, working alone six days a week. He is married with four children ranging in age from ten to four years. On his one day off, Henry is building a house for his family home.

Henry is asking for a loan to enable him to purchase more cosmetics, perfumes and also some food to sell in his shop.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics, perfumes and also some food to sell in his shop.

loans.name: Joesph

texts.en:
Joseph is 26 years old and is employed by a large maize mealing factory, which allows him to rent their equipment and conduct his own business outside of regular factory hours.

Joseph is married with a nine-month old boy and also supports his eight-year old brother. Joseph’s wife sells charcoal from their family home and some of the loan amount will help to fund her business.

His dream is to buy a plot of land on which to build his family home and eventually have a small poultry farm and wholesale business.

loans.use: Joseph is looking for a loan to buy more maize to meal for his retail maize mealing business.

loans.name: Stone Quarry Association Group

texts.en:
The Mukono Stone Quarry Association is a group of 23 men and women who have brick-making businesses and are applying for a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Alice N. is the chairperson of this group. She is responsible for encouraging the group’s members to repay the loan. She is looking for a loan to enable her to employ three more workers in her brick-making business.

Alice employs five workers in her brick-making business. Each of her workers can produce 500 bricks per day, which she sells to retail customers, mainly to build their own homes. She has had two previous loans that enabled her to employ two full-time workers. Alice’s business has been running since 2003.

Alice and her husband, also a brick-maker, have four children (aged 24, 21, 18 and 12 years). They also live with and support her mother and her two nephews.

Their dream is to eventually be able to buy some land on which to build homes to rent to local villagers. She is also hopeful that her youngest child will qualify as an accountant.

loans.use: This is a group loan to enable the 23 men and women group members, who each have a brick-making business, to employ additional workers and purchase more clay.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 26 years old and has been selling bananas at the market for three years. She purchases them directly from the farmers and sells them to locals. Lydia works alone at the market while caring for her two-week old baby. Her two other children attend primary school.

Lydia is not married and she, along with her three children, live with her sister and her husband and their two children.

She dreams of making enough money to enable her to start a grocery store.

loans.use: Lydia is looking for a loan to purchase more bananas to sell at her stall at the local market.

loans.name: Kiwalazi East B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jane A.. She is currently in the business of selling maize and is requesting a loan to add more capital. Jane is 45 years old and is married. She has 6 children ranging from age 11 to 26 and her children go to school. Each week, Jane makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to finish her house, which is under construction.

Jane is joined in her small group by Norah A., Gladys N., Jane K., and Jane A.. Norah A. has a business selling matooke and wants to boost business. Gladys N. is currently operating a business in clothing sales and wants a loan to purchase in bulk. Jane K. operates a business selling clothes and wants to re-invest in her business. Jane A. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and is requesting a loan to put up a stall.

loans.use: To expand maize business

loans.name: Makoma Central A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Margret A.. She is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and is requesting a loan to add capital. Margret is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant farmer. She has 8 children ranging from age 6 to 21 and her children go to school. Each week, Margret makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land.

Margret is joined in her small group by Nakecho K., Pamela A., Base N., and Rose K.. Nakecho K. has a business in tailoring and wants to purchase more cloth fabric. Pamela A. is currently operating a weaving and mat selling business and wants a loan to add working capital. Base N. operates a business in fish sales and wants to boost business. Rose K. is currently in the business of selling vegetables and is requesting a loan to construct a vegetable stall.

loans.use: To boost vegetable selling business

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James employs four workers in his brick-making business, which has been in operation for three years. Each of his workers can produce 500 bricks per day which he sells to retail customers, mainly to build their homes. He has had two previous loans that he has used to increase his workforce.

James 25 years old and is married with a six-month-old daughter. He also supports his 18-year old sister, who is still at school, as well as his 4-year-old nephew, who has just started school. His wife sells fruit that she buys from local farmers at a kiosk from their home. Some of the loan amount will be used to improve her business as well.

James hopes to grow his business and eventually buy some land to build a hostel to house locals students. His dream for his children is for them to finish school and further education, and find professions of their own.

loans.use: James is seeking a loan to enable him to employ two more workers in his brick-making business.

loans.name: Ndfuna

texts.en:
Ndfuna (age 48) has had a shop at The Nile Market since 1997. She sells a variety of grocery products to the local villagers. She is married and has six children ranging in age from 26 to 16-year old twins. Her husband is a school teacher and supports her business enterprise.

She hopes one day to breed chickens at her home and be able to sell eggs and poultry to the market.

loans.use: Ndfuna is looking for a loan to help grow her business by increasing stock levels in her shop.

loans.name: Oliva's Ujirani Mwema Group

texts.en:
Oliva is 25 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 1-3 years old. Oliva is an eggs and chicken seller, a business she started in 2004. She can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more chickens for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in shops and electical equipment selling.

loans.use: To buy more hens for her business

loans.name: Makoma Central B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Grace N.. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add more shelves and stock. Grace is 31 years old and is married. She has 5 children ranging from age 2 to 9 and her children go to school. Each week, Grace makes approximately UGX 1500 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in her business.

Grace is joined in her small group by Nalongo O., Salimati N., Jane A., and Jennifer T.. Nalongo O. has a business running a retail shop and wants to increase stock. Salimati N. is currently operating a business in mat weaving and selling and wants a loan to expand business. Jane A. operates a business selling mats and wants to add to her business. Jennifer T. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add more commodities.

loans.use: To re-stock her shop with more commodities

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The entrepreneur will make the purchase of clothing in bulk to augment her stock and satisfy her customers.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Eusebia

texts.en:
Eusebia is in her late thirties, and she and her husband are raising five boys and four girls. Eusebia defines herself as a many-sided entrepreneur who does everything in her power to support her family and provide good education with her children.

She sells new and used clothing from her house. She also prepares natural juices which she sells with fried vegetables and pork meat in a school next to her house, located in the Quita Sueño community of San Cristobal. Eusebia hopes that her business’ growth will help her put aside money with the intention of setting a cafeteria next to the public school of the community.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials to prepare fried food; and clothing in bulk to retail in her community.

loans.name: Halim

texts.ru:
Halim is 23 year old married man. He needs a loan to help him maintain his cattle breeding business. In the first half of January, cold and dry weather that predominated in Tajikistan seriously harmed Tajik ahriculture and livestock farming. Tajik cattle breeders found themselves in a difficult situation because they didn't have enough cattle food. They only had a half of the needed amounts of hay in their reserves. However, slottering the cattle at that point in time wasn't profitable. To resolve his problem, Halim requested a loan from Miconvest. The loan helped him to restore his cattle food reserves and continue maining his livestock.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

Халим женат, ему 23 года. Ему необходимы деньги для приобретения и разведения скота. Хлодная и засушливая погода, стоявшая в Таджикистане в первой половине января, нанесла серьезный урон по таджикскому сельскому хозяйству и животноводству. Таджикиские скотоводы попали в затруднительное положение - кормить скотину скоро будет нечем. Заготовлено лишь меньше половины необходимого количества сена, причем в некоторых хозяйствах коровам дают сено из запасов на зиму. Однако и забивать животных невыгодно. Для этого, Халим как и другие скотоводы попал в затруднительное положение. В решение проблемы ему помог, получивший кредит в Микроинвест. Он запасся сразу кормом для скота, что стало легче содержать скот.

loans.use: To restore the cattle food reserves

loans.name: Katwe A(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Suzan K.. She is currently in the business of selling new clothes and is requesting a loan to buy more clothes. Suzan is 26 years old and is married with a husband who has a butcher's shop. She has 2 children ranging from age 4 to 7 and her children go to school. Each week, Suzan makes approximately UGX 60000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a residential house. Suzan has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to buy more clothes and the loan was paid back on time.

Suzan is joined in her small group by Fatuma K., Joy W. and Fida T.. Fatuma K. has a business selling fabrics and wants to add more stock. Joy W. is currently operating a bar business and wants a loan to add furniture and purchase a television. Fida T. operates a business in used clothing sales and wants to purchase a sewing machine.

loans.use: To add capital to clothing business and to increase clothing purchases

loans.name: Israel

texts.en:
Israel, aged 38 years, has been a fisherman and fish seller to customers for seven years. He is looking for a loan to enable him to buy maize, rice and flour to expand his existing fishing trade by selling grain to shops.

He is hardworking and determined, as he has six of his own children to support, along with five orphans who live with him and his wife.

loans.use: Israel isseeking a loan to enable him to buy maize, rice and flour to expand his existing fishing trade by selling grain to shops.

loans.name: Katwe A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Alice M.. She is currently in the business of spare part sales and is requesting a loan to increase stock. Alice is 29 years old and is married, with a husband who is a mechanic for work. She has 4 children ranging from age 3 to 11 and her children go to school. Each week, Alice makes approximately UGX in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children. Alice has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to buy spare parts and the loan was paid back on time.

Alice is joined in her small group by Kasifa N., Margret N. and Barbara Nakiranda. Kasifa N. has a business selling chicken and wants to start a poultry farming business. Margret N. is currently operating a business in charcoal sales and wants a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal. Barbara Nakiranda operates a business selling charcoal and wants to extend to bulk selling.

loans.use: To purchase more spare parts and add stock

loans.name: Bi Mkubwa's Ujirani Mwema Group

texts.en:
Bi Mkubwa is 32 years old and is a married woman with three children, ages 11, 7 and 1 years old. Bi Mkubwa owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more food items  for her business.

loans.name: Rahma's Mkombozi. Group

texts.en:
Rahma is 29 years old and is a married woman with three children, ages 13,10 and 8 years old. Rahma owns a small charcoal store that she started in 2006. Her store also carries food items for sale. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $170 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items and charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in grocery and salon.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Swaumu's Juhudi Group

texts.en:
Swaumu is 45 years old and is a married woman with four children, ages 20, 9, 5 and 3 years old. Swaumu is a hard-working business woman who started her business in 1999. Everyday, she works from 10am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more commodities for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in poultry keeping and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for her business.

loans.name: Hanifa's Tujitume Group

texts.en:
Hanifa is 34 years old and is a married woman with three children, ages 15,11 and 7 years old. Hanifa owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2000. Everyday, she works from 8am to 4pm at her business.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who run businesses dealing in food vending, business and trading.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Rosette

texts.en:
Rosette has a dairy farm and piggery and employs five full time workers. Rosette has run the business for five years and currently owns five Friesian cows and 20 pigs.

She is 38 years old and a single mother with six children ranging in age from 8 to 17. All her children are in school and her eldest child hopes to become a lawyer.

Rosette’s hope for her business is to increase the number of cows in order to reduce costs so that everyone in her community can have more affordable milk.

loans.use: Rosette is seeking a loan to purchase another cow as well as some additional feed for her cows and pigs.

loans.name: Khamida

texts.en:
Khamida is 25 years old and is married. Khamida is a cloth seller; she started this clothing business in 2007. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm and earn an average monthly profit of $230 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for this business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Katwe A(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mariam N.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to buy more cloth fabric. Mariam is 23 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has 2 children, aged 1 and 4, and one child goes to school. Each week, Mariam makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save to cater for basic needs. Mariam has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Mariam is joined in her small group by Mwajjuma N. and Betty N.. Mwajjuma N. has a business selling cold drinks and wants to purchase a fridge. Betty N. is currently operating a business selling new clothes and wants a loan to increase her purchases.

loans.use: To buy more fabric and thread to expand tailoring business

loans.name: Katwe A(Iv) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Florence K.. She is currently in the business of selling mobile phone accessories and is requesting a loan to purchase more chargers and housings devices. Florence is 39 years old and is married. Her husband is a retired teacher. She has 5 children ranging from age 5.5 to 23 and her children go to school. Each week, Florence makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to invest in her business. Florence has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 100000 in order to buy a counter and more phones and the loan was paid back on time.

Florence is joined in her small group by Robinah M., Juliet W., Betty N., and Mariam N.. Robinah M. has a business in charcoal sales and wants to expand to bulk selling. Juliet W. is currently operating a grocery store business and wants a loan to purchase more groceries. Betty N. operates a beauty salon business and wants to stock more hair oils and braids. Mariam N. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to add more capital.

loans.use: To add more stock to shop

loans.name: Mashrafhon

texts.en:
Mashrafhon is a happy mother of 5 children. She is 50 years old. She sells clothing for children and she loves her job very much. She is fond of selling. She has been selling for 7 years, and she has good experience as an excellent seller of children's clothes. She likes to help her clients choose clothes for their children, and she said that many clients are satisfied with her service.

She brings her goods from the wholesale market and her elder children help her carry the heavy bags of goods. In the near future she wants to go to the wholesale market to purchase spring goods, which are provided by suppliers from China.

She wants to ask for a loan from Kiva lenders for expanding her assortment to include spring goods. (In the photo you can see Mashrafhon on the left and her credit expert, Nargiz, on the right).

loans.use: Purchase spring goods.

loans.name: Fotil

texts.ru:
Fotil K. is 47 years old. He is married and has 2 children. He has a high school education. He works as a supervisor in the local farm called "Dyust". "Dyust" maintans an area of 23.10 hectares. He supervises a group of 15 people (which includes his family members). On the farm, the workers plant cotton, wheat, corn, and onions. He has been a client of MicroInvest since 2006. The first credit was in the amount of 2,000 som ($575). Using that credit, Fotil planted onions on 2 hectares of land. He was able to get a profit of 5,000 som ($1450). Using that money he fixed his house. This time, he is asking for 3,000 som ($875), so he could plant onions and wheat on 1 hetare of land each.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

Кодиров Фотил Нодирович - 47 лет. Женат имеет 2-х детей. Имеет среде специальное образование. Председатель дехканского хозяйства «Дуст» . Дехканское хозяйство «Дуст» имеет 23,10 гектаров земли. Под его руководством работают около 15 работников (в.ч члены его семьи). Клиент сеет хлопок, пшеницу, кукурузу и лук. Кредитуется в МЗФ «Микроинвест» начиная с 2006 года. Первый кредит был в размере 2000 сом. На полученный кредит клиент посеял 1 га лука. Получил прибыль около 5000 сомони. На полученный доход отремонтировал дом. На получаемый кредит хочет посеять 1 гектар лука и 1 гектар пшеницы.

loans.use: На получаемый кредит хочет посеять 1 гектар лука и 1 гектар пшеницы.

loans.name: Mohira

texts.ru:
Mohira J., who is 34, has a high school education, is married, and has 4 children. She lives in the village Yangikurgan in the Shahristan region. Mohira doesn't work outside of home. At home, she takes care of the cattle. Her older son also helps her with this business. In the morning, he pastures cattle in the mountain plains with neighboring children. In the evening, he comes back home. Mohira's husband works in a farm. He has only seasonal profit. That makes their cattle business their single source of income during the winter time. Mohira has been a client of MicroInvest since the middle of 2007. Using the first credit, she was able to buy a cow, and using the second one, she bought 2 young bulls. She plans to use this new credit to purchase more cattle.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer.

Жумабоева Мохира Шарифовна - 34 лет, образование среднее, замужем имеет 4-х детей. Мохира живет в селе Янгикурган Шахристанского района. Мохира не работает. Дома занимается откормом скота. Ее в этом деле помогает старший сын. Утром он пасет скот на горных равнинах с соседскими детьми а вечером приходит домой. Муж Мохири работает в дехканском хозяйстве. Его доход сезонный. Зимой единственный источник дохода это скот. Мохира кредитуется в МЗФ «Микроинвет» начиная с середине 2007 года. На полученный она купила корову а на второй кредит 2-х бычков. На новый кредит она планирует купить телят .

loans.use: To purchase additional cattle

loans.name: Gulnara

texts.en: Gulnara (her father is pictured ) was born in 1980.  She is single and lives in Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan.Two years ago, she started this business. Now she needs a loan of $950 to buy a cow.

loans.use: to buy  a cow

loans.name: Murod

texts.ru:
Murod G. works as the chairman of the farming collective “Malikabonu.” He is married and has 5 children. He has been growing livestock for 18 years. His wife, Hurmatoy, and his sons help him in his work. Murod raises animal feed on the fields of the collective and stores it for the winter. He would like to use his loan to purchase several heads of livestock thereby expanding his livestock count.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Гаппаров Мурод Сатторович - работает председателем дехканского хозяйства «Маликабону». Женат , имеет 5 детей. Откормом скота занимается более 18 лет. Ему помогают жена Хурматой и сыновия. На полях дехканского хозяйства он выращивает корм и запасает на зимний период. На получаемый кредит он хочет купить несколько голов крупно рогатого скота тем самим увеличить количество скота.

loans.use: Purchase livestock

loans.name: Haidarov

texts.ru:
H. Haidarov is a young, 26 years old man and owns a business that sells food. He has 2 children and his wife is a homemaker. After finishing school he went into business with his father. 6 years ago his business separated from his father’s business. Today, H. sells granulated sugar, sugar cubes and candy. He will use his loan to increase his product assortment.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Хайдаров Хомид молодой человек в возросте 26 лет занимается бизнесом по продаже продуктов питания.Имеет 2 детей ,жена домохозяйка.После окончания школы занимался торговлей продуктов вместе со своим отцом. Затем уже 6 лет как его бизнес отдеился от бизнеса отца.В данное время Хомид торгует сахар песком, комковым сахаром,конфетами .В дальнейшем хочет получив займ увеличить ассортимент.

loans.use: Purchase food for resale

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia is 25 years old and is a single woman. Rukia is business woman who started her retail business in 2007. Everyday, she works hard at her store from 8am to 6pm.

She now hopes to receive a loan in order to buy additional items for her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en:
Bahati is 27 years old and is a married woman with one child who is four and a half years old. Bahati is a business and trading woman; she started this retail business in 2007. Everyday, she works from 10am to 6pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more commodities for her retail store.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for her business.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is married woman with two children, ages 2-12 years old. Rehema is a soft drink seller; she started this business in 2006. Everyday, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Katwe B(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Esther N.. She is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase more hair chemicals and a dryer. Esther is 27 years old and is married, with a husband who sells produce for work. She has 2 children, aged 6 and 10, and both of her children go to school. Each week, Esther makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to add to her business. Esther has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to buy a hair dryer and the loan was paid back on time.

Esther is joined in her small group by Eva N., Amina N., and Hadija N.. Eva N. has a business selling new clothes and wants to purchase more clothes and start a business selling shoes. Amina N. is currently operating a business in used clothing sales and wants a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Hadija N. operates a restaurant business and wants to venture into another business.

loans.use: To boost beauty salon business and offer better quality services

loans.name: Katwe B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Lamula K.. She is currently in the business of new clothing sales and is requesting a loan to purchase in bulk. Lamula is 32 years old and is married with a husband who sells oil for work. She has 12 children ranging from age 4 to 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Lamula makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children. Lamula has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 100000 in order to buy more clothes and the loan was paid back on time.

Lamula is joined in her small group by Aisha N., Robina N., Kasifa N., and Gertrude K.. Aisha N. has a business in clothing sales and wants to add more stock. Robina N. is currently operating a restaurant business and wants a loan to add furniture. Kasifa N. operates a business selling charcoal and wants to expand to bulk selling. Gertrude K. is currently in the business of running a salon and is requesting a loan to buy a hair dryer.

loans.use: To increase clothing purchases

loans.name: Otilia

texts.pt:
Otilia G. is 24 years old and native to the district of Matutuine in the province of Maputo. As a child she did not have the opportunity to study, and due to her parents' lack of conditions she only attended school until the 7th grade. As a result she found herself obliged to go to South Africa to search for work. However, at her place of employment she came to marry a Mozambican man in that neighboring country. She says that they lived there for some time and the conditions did not improve so they had to return to Mozambique.

As she is alone at home and her current house offers only minimum security, she proposed to her husband that they solicit a loan so they could construct a home with conventional materials. This loan goes to purchase cement and labor since some materials they had already acquired with their family savings. She envisions that after finishing her home and furnishings that she will begin other investments like raising cattle or goats.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Otilia G., de 24 anos de idade, natural do Distrito de Matutuine, provincia da Maputo, durante a sua infancia não teve possibilidade de estudar, disse devido a falta de condiçoes dos pais, tendo terminado na 7ª Classe. Assim, viu se obrigada a ir para Africa do Sul procurar emprego. Porem, no lugar de emprego veio o casamento com um Mocambicano residente naquele Pais vizinho. Diz que viveram la por um tempo e as condiçoes nao favoreceram teve de voltar a Moçambique e como ela está sozinha no lar e a casa que tem nao lhe oferece minimas condicoes de segurança propos ao marido para irem solicitarem emprestimo de forma a construir uma com material convencional. O emprestimo de 30.000,00MT foi para compra de cimento e pagamento de mao de obra, pois uma parte de material ja tinham adquirido com poupancas familiares. Tem como perpectivas depois de terminar as construcoes mobilar e iniciar com outros investimentos tipo criacao de gado bovino ou caprino.

loans.use: To buy materials to build family house

loans.name: Katwe B(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Christine N.. She is currently in the business of selling dry fish and is requesting a loan to increase her fish purchases. Christine is 30 years old and is married with a husband who sells used clothes for work. She has 2 children ranging from age 5 to 10 and her children go to school. Each week, Christine makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to cater for the family's basic needs. Christine has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to buy more fish and the loan was paid back on time.

Christine is joined in her small group by Ruth M., Salamula E., and Saida N.. Ruth M. has a business selling spare parts and wants to re-stock her shop. Salamula E. is currently operating a business in new clothing sales and wants a loan to purchase a counter and more clothes. Saida N. operates a business of used clothing sales and wants to increase her stock.

loans.use: To add working capital to fish selling business

loans.name: Raquel

texts.pt:
Raquel T. is 52 years old and native to the Matutuine district in the province of Maputo. As a child she was unable to attend school due to the distance between her home and the school, and being a girl in her culture with discrimination between sons and daughters she was only able to attend until the 3rd grade. She grew up with her parents.

At 19 years old she married and had 6 children. She has suffered great pains from the civil war between Frelimo and Renamo having been kidnapped by the enemy army, and even today the effects of the war continue in her memory.

Thanks to the access to credit she has been able to structure her life and without it her life would have continued to be very difficult. With her activity she is able to support a family of 8 people, between children and grandchildren. Despite having an official husband, he seldom helps the family due to his low monthly income.

With this loan of $1,125US she intends to purchase inventory both of new and different products following the necessities of her customers. It should be noted that by her great entrepreneurship she sells on foot at different markets each week in the district of Matutuine. In the future as her age increases she realizes that she is not going to be able to handle the various trips to sell at the markets so she intends to build a small commercial establishment in the village of Bela Vista.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Raquel T., de 52 anos de idade, natural do Distrito de Matutuine, provincia do Maputo, durante a sua infáncia não teve possibilidade de estudar, devido a distancia que tinha da casa para escola e sendo mulher por questoes culturas havia descriminacao entre filhos e filhas, tendo frequentado até 3ª classe. Cresceu junto dos pais. Aos 19 anos casou se e deste casamento naeceu 6 filhos, diz ter ficado com grandes magoas da guerra civil entre Frelimo e Renamo, tendo sido raptada pelas exercito da oposicao e ate hoje as sequelas desta guerra continuam ficaram registados na memoria dela. Diz que graça ao acesso do credito que consegue estruturar a sua vida, porque se não fosse a vida continuaria lhe dificil. Com a sua actividade consegue suportar uma familia de 8 pessoas, dentre filhos e netos, apesar de ter um marido funcionario, mas este poucas vezes tem ajudado a familia, devido a baixa renda mensal. Com o emprestimo de 27.000,00MT, tenciona reforcar o stock de diferentes artigos e adquirir novos produtos segundo as necessidades dos clientes. De salientar que por grande empreendedorismo dela faz vendas ambulatorios nas diferentes feiras semanais realizadas no distrito de Matutuine. No futuro como a idade vai aumentando, esta consciente que nao vai aguentar continuar fazer varias viagens para vender nas feiras, pretende construir um pequeno estabelecimento comercial na vila da Bela Vista.

loans.use: To increase stock in her business

loans.name: Aissatou

texts.fr:
Mrs Aïssatou D. is married and a member of the Ngollar Village Bank. She buys wood and pays for the labor to turn it into charcoal, which she then sells. She has been a customer of the program for five and a half years and has always respected her commitments. Her income enables her to provide for the needs of her family and buy livestock. To pursue her business activity, Aissatou is requesting a 12th loan that she plans to repay after six months in one installment.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Mme Aïssatou D., mariée, membre du Banc villageois de Ngollar.Elle achète du bois et paie la main d'oeuvre pour la fabrique du charbon qu'elle vend.Elle est cliente du programme depuis 5 ans et demie et a toujours respecté ses engagements.Ses revenus lui permettent de subvenir au besoin de sa famille et de s'acheter du bétail. Pour poursuivre son activité, Aissatou sollicite ce 12ème prêt qu'elle compte rembourser au bout de 6 mois en une seule échéance

loans.use: To buy wood and labor

loans.name: Katwe B(Iv) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jackline K.. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal. Jackline is 33 years old and is married with a husband who sells produce for work. She has 3 children ranging from age 7 to 15 and her children go to school. Each week, Jackline makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children. Jackline has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 350000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Jackline is joined in her small group by Edith K., Agnes N. and Sarah A.. Edith K. has a business selling used clothes and wants to purchase more clothes to sell. Agnes N. is currently operating a laundry business and wants a loan to put up sign posts and buy dry irons. Sarah A. operates a business in used clothing sales and wants to increase the stock of clothes.

loans.use: To increase charcoal purchases and sales

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a laser printer

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Action Now: Kenya (ANK) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Antonio

texts.pt:
Antonio N. is 46 years old and a native to the Quelimane district in the Zambezia province. As a child Antonio did not have the opportunity to study and only attended school until the 4th grade. He says he grew up with his mother and stepfather. At age 15 he affiliated himself with the F.A.L.M. where he stayed for 5 years until he was discharged. He was living in the province of Maputo at the time and in the same year he returned to Quelimane again and began working in a family carpentry shop with the goal to learn the art.

He married a young girl who months later became pregnant and everything in Antonio's life changed. The cost of living increased so he decided to return to the city of Maputo leaving his wife with her parents. In Maputo he was able to win a contract to work in South Africa; this in 1986 when the first President of Mozambique, Samora Machel died. This situation forced the authorities to cancel the contracts with Mozambique emigrants so he ended up working that year in a restaurant in Catembe.

In 1994 he changed jobs working as a carpenter in the town of Bela-Vista. In 1998 he ended his contract and, tired of looking for work, opened a small business producing furniture. With the difficulty of acquiring wood in the local market he almost gave up on the activity but with access to credit through HLUVUKU he opted to run the business with financing. With this loan he intends to purchase wood in the city of Maputo. With his business he can support a family of 8 people and with the savings he is building a home with conventional materials. He also works with 2 other people who are heads of households.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Antonio N., de 46 anos de idade ,natural do Distrito de Quelimane, provincia da Zambezia, durante a sua infáncia não teve possibilidade de estudar, tendo frequentado até 4ª classe, diz que cresceu com a mae e o padrasto. Aos 15 anos foi afiliar se as F.A.L.M, onde ficou durante cinco ano dai foi desmobilizado, dizer que a desmobilizaçao ocorreu na provincia de maputo onde ate entao se encontrava e no mesmo ano volta a Quelimane provincia de origem e começou a trabalhar numa carpintaria Familiar com o proposito de aprender a arte. Lá se casa com uma jovem que meses depois ficou gravida e, tudo mudou na vida dele, o custo de vida aumentou e assim decidiu voltar á cidade de Maputo, deixando a esposa com os pais e em maputo veio a conseguir um contrato para ir trabalhar na Africa do Sul, isto em 1986 ano que morreu o primeiro presidente de Moçambique Samora Machel, situaçao que obrigou as autoridades a cancelar os contratos de emigrantes Moçambicanos, ainda no mesmo ano regressa e passa a trabalhar num restaurante na Catembe. Em 1994 muda de emprego, passando a desempenhar funcoes de carpinteiro na vila de Bela-Vista. Em 1998 termina o contrato de trabalho e cansado de pedir emprego abriu uma micro empresa de producao de mobiliario. Com a dificuldade de aquisicao de madeira no mercado local quase que disistia da actividade, mas com facilidade de acesso ao credito na HLUVUKU optou por recorrer a esta instituicao para o financiamento. Com o emprestimo de 10.000,00MT pretende comprar madeira na cidade de Maputo. Com este negocio consegue suportar uma familia de 8 pessoas, e com as poupancas esta a construir uma casa de material convecional. Tambem trabalha com outras duas pessoas chefes de familias.

loans.use: To buy wood for furniture Making

loans.name: Budumuli East A A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Fatuma M.. She is currently in the business of running a kiosk and is requesting a loan to open up another branch. Fatuma is 25 years old and is married. Her husband has a phone accessories shop. She has 3 children ranging from age 5 to 9 and her children go to school. Each week, Fatuma makes approximately UGX 125000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. Fatuma has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 600000 in order to add stock to the kiosk and the loan was paid back on time.

Fatuma is joined in her small group by Prossy N., Zamu W., Fatuma B., and Teopista N.. Prossy N. has a business running a drug shop and wants to purchase more drugs. Zamu W. is currently operating a beauty salon business and wants a loan to purchase a fridge and start selling cold drinks. Fatuma B. operates a retail shop business and wants to purchase a fridge. Teopista N. is currently in the business of running a grocery store and is requesting a loan to add more groceries.

loans.use: To open up another kiosk and expand business

loans.name: Joao Eriasse

texts.pt:
João Eriasse C. is 42 years old and native of the Beira district in the Sofala province in Mozambique. During his childhood João did not have the opportunity to study due to social situations. He lost his father when he was young and went to live with his grandparents.

In his childhood he learned to fish since that is what most people do in the zone where he was born. When he was 18 years old he joined the army and was transferred to the Maputo province. After working 3 years he was discharged.

He is married and the father of 3 children the youngest of which are students. He works as a fisherman, and his wife helps him sell his fish. Both of them work in agriculture during periods of low production.

With this loan João intends to purchase fishing nets. He doesn't have sufficient funds to fix them and lately the fishing hasn't been very lucrative due to the drastic reduction in fish in the Maputo River. In the future he wants to improve his boat and buy a motor so he can fish in the Indian Ocean.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Joao Eriasse C., de 42 anos de idade, natural do Distrito de Beira, provincia da Sofala, centro de Moçamique, durante a sua infáncia não teve possibilidade de estudar, devido a situaçoes sociais muito cedo perdeu o seu pai onde viu se obrigado a viver com os avos. Desde a infancia que aprendeu a actividade de pesca, uma vez que uma maioria exerce a mesma actividade na zona onde ele nasceu. Quando tinha 18 anos foi incorporado no exercito e tendo sido transferido para Maputo provincia, onde trabalhou 03 anos, tendo sido desmobilizado. Casado e pai de 3 filhos e todos menores e estudantes, ele ocupa-se como pescador e a esposa ajuda-lhe nas vendas do produto pesqueiro e ambos no periodo de fraca producao dedicam-se a agricultura.
