Maria, Cristina, and Saturna dream that their children become professionals and that they have greater cash for their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Maria, Cristina y Saturna pertenecen al Banco Comunal Santa Isabel D. Acosvinchos hace 1, 1, 3 años respectivamente, las socias son naturales del distrito D. Acosvinchos que esta ubicada a 2 horas D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho.

Maria es casada, tiene 58 años y 12 hijos D. los cuales 6 viven con ella, Maria elabora panes típicos D. la zona, el horneado D. sus panes lo realiza en un horno alquilado. Además Maria venD. carne en la feria del distrito.

Por otro lado Cristina es madre soltera, tiene 49 años y 3 hijos, Cristina venD. carne en la feria D. su distrito, los animales son beneficiados por ella misma.

Mientras que Saturna es casada, tiene 53 años y 8 hijos D. los cuales 4 viven con ella, Saturna compra y venD. cereales, productos que compra en las ferias y los venD. en el mercado D. abastos D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho. Además en temporadas compra tara y lo venD. en Ayacucho.

Maria, Cristina y Saturna necesitan préstamos D. 600 soles, 300 soles, 1500 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. cerdo, harina, carnero, oveja, maíz, trigo, arveja.

Los sueños D. Maria, Cristina y Saturna son que sus hijos sean profesionales y mayor capital para sus negocios.

loans.use: Purchase of various meats and grains for the women's respective businesses.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.es:
Josefina has been a member of the communal bank "Santa Isabel de Acosvinchos" for one year. She is from the Acosvinchos district, which is two hours away from the city of Ayacucho.

Josefina is married, 38 years old, and has four children. She bakes traditional regional breads such as the chapla. She performs this work using her mother's oven, and she sells the breads at her store. She runs this small grocery store, while at the same time raising and fattening animals.

Josefina needs a loan for $525 which she will invest in purchasing flour and sugar.

She will use her savings to purchase cattle and to meet any future needs. Josefina dreams of her children becoming professionals, of improving her home, and of growing her bakery business.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Josefina es socia del Banco Comunal Santa Isabel de Acosvinchos hace 1 año, Josefina es natural del distrito de Acosvinchos que esta ubicada a 2 horas de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Josefina es casada, tiene 38 años y 4 hijos, Josefina elabora panes típicos de la zona como la “chapla”, actividad que realiza en el horno de su mama y lo vende en su tienda. Además tiene una pequeña tienda de abarrotes, también se dedica a la crianza y engorde de animales.

Josefina necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de harina y azúcar.

Sus ahorros son para comprar ganado vacuno y alguna necesidad en el futuro. Los sueños de Josefina son que sus hijos sean profesionales, mejorar su casa y que su panadería crezca.

loans.use: Purchase flour and sugar for her bakery.

loans.name: Rosa Victoria

texts.es:
Rosa joined the communal bank "Santa Isabel de Acosvinchos" one year ago. She lives in the Acosvinchos district, which is located two hours from the city of Ayacucho.

Rosa is married, 47 years old, and has four children. At first, Rosa had a restaurant and a bar, an activity that she abandoned because her husband drank a lot. Later, when he had converted to an evangelical religion, she started up her businesses again, but this time just a restaurant, with very little cash. Currently, her business has grown, and she provides food for employees of various institutions in the district. Her restaurant is located on the main plaza of the district in her sister-in-law's house.

Rosa needs a loan for $1050 which she will invest in buying rice, potatoes, oil, sugar, grains, noodles, and gas.

She will use her savings for her childrens' higher educations and for some future need. She dreams of opening another restaurant in her house, improving her home, and her children becoming professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Rosa pertenece al Banco Comunal Santa Isabel de Acosvinchos hace 1 año, Josefina es natural del distrito de Acosvinchos que esta ubicada a 2 horas de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Rosa es casada, tiene 47 años y 4 hijos, Rosa al inicio tenía un restaurante y bar, actividad que dejo de realizar porque su esposo tomaba mucho, luego de convertirse a la religión evangelista inició nuevamente su negocio pero ya solo como restaurante con muy poco capital, actualmente su negocio ha crecido, da pensión a los trabajadores de las diferentes instituciones del distrito. Su restaurante esta ubicado en la plaza principal del distrito en casa de su cuñada.

Rosa necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, papa, aceite, azúcar, cereales, fideo y gas.

Sus ahorros lo utilizará para la educación superior de sus hijos y para alguna necesidad. Los sueños de Rosa son abrir otro restaurante en su casa, mejorar su casa y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Purchasing rice, potatoes, oil, sugar, grains, noodles, and gas for her restaurant.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To Buy 80 lbs. of Shrimp, 80 lbs. of Fillet, 80 lbs. of Fish and 80 lbs. of Conch.

payments.comment: La cuota es de US $ 29.82 dolares.

loans.name: Domitila

texts.es:
Domitila has belonged to the Saint Isabel of Acosvinchos Communal Bank for 1 year. She is a native of the district of Acosvinchos that this located 2 hours from the city of Ayacucho.

Domitila is married, 62 years old and has 6 children of which 1 lives with her. Domitila and her husband make Andean tiles. They employ laborers, who dry them in the sun and subsequently cook them in the oven. They sell their product to intermediaries in their own town.

In addition, Domitila works breeding and fattening animals, that she sells in the animal fair of Ayacucho.

Domitila needs a loan of 2000 soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of cattle and for the payment of the laborers.

The dreams of Domitila are that her children become professionals and that her business prospers.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Domitila pertenece al Banco Comunal Santa Isabel D. Acosvinchos hace 1 año, Domitila es natural del distrito D. Acosvinchos que esta ubicada a 2 horas D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho.

Domitila es casada, tiene 62 años y 6 hijos D. los cuales 1 vive con ella, Domitila junto a su esposo hacen tejas andinas, hacen labrar con peones, luego se hace secar al sol posteriormente se quema en el horno, las ventas lo realiza en su mismo pueblo a intermediarios.

Además Domitila se dedica a la crianza y engorD. D. animales, que venD. en la feria D. animales D. Ayacucho.

Domitila necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. ganado vacuno y para el pago D. los peones.

Los sueños D. Domitila es que sus hijos sean profesionales y que su negocio prospere.

loans.use: To buy cattle and to pay laborers.

loans.name: Natalia

texts.es:
Natalia P. provides for her family by herself because her husband is working in Brazil in order to be able to give the family better living conditions. She lives in a rural area near the city of La Paz. She currently has three milk cows that produce 30 liters of milk, which she sells each day. This is how she supports her family. Natalia is requesting her sixth loan and has an impeccable credit history.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Natalia P. mantiene sola a su familia ya que su esposo se encuentra trabajando en Brasil para dar mejores condiciones de vida a esta, ella vive en una zona rural de la ciudad de La Paz, en la actualidad cuenta con tres vacas lecheras, las cuales le proporcionan treinta litros de leche los cuales los comercializa diariamente y es con esto que mantiene a su familia. Actualmente solicita el sexto credito teniendo un historial de credito impecable.

loans.use: To buy balanced feed for her cows

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Lucia has belonged to the Saint Isabel of Acosvinchos Communal Bank for 1 year. Lucia is a native of the district of Acosvinchos that this located 2 hours from the city of Ayacucho. In her Communal Bank she has learned to feed her children, to avoid illnesses and to be punctual.

Lucia is married, is 30 years old and has 2 children. Lucia sells fruits in the market of the district on Sundays. With the aid of her son, she buys the fruits in the Nery Garcia market in Ayacucho. Also, Lucia makes loaves of “chapla” bread and biscochos (a type of cookie), which she sells from her house and in the market. In addition, Lucia has a small grocery store in her house.

Lucia needs a loan of 1500 soles that will be invested in the purchase of sugar, rice, flour, noodles and oil.

The dreams of Lucia are that her children become professionals, to live in the city of Ayacucho and to run her business in the city.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Lucia pertenece al Banco Comunal Santa Isabel de Acosvinchos hace 1 año, Josefina es natural del distrito de Acosvinchos que esta ubicada a 2 horas de la ciudad de Ayacucho. En su Banco Comunal aprendió a como alimentar a sus hijos, evitar enfermedades y ser puntual.

Lucia es casada, tiene 30 años y 2 hijos, Lucia vende frutas en el mercado del distrito los días domingos, con la ayuda de su hijo, las frutas lo compra del mercado Nery garcía en Ayacucho. También Lucia elabora panes “chapla”, biscochos, sus ventas los realiza en su casa y en el mercado. Además Lucia tiene una pequeña tienda de abarrotes en su casa.

Lucia necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de azúcar, arroz, harina, fideos y aceite.

Los sueños de Lucia son que sus hijos sean profesionales, vivir en la ciudad de Ayacucho y realizar su negocio en la ciudad.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, flour, noodles and oil.

loans.name: Norma Leticia

texts.en:
I, Mrs. Norma Leticia, have been selling used and new clothing for more than 2 years. This business is the source of income for my family. I operate this business from my home, so that I do not neglect my three children. Now I need more merchandise, especially new merchandise to sell because my clients are asking for certain styles of clothing. I am seeking a loan of $1200 to buy new better quality merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Jenny Dean, Kiva Volunteer.

L. Sra. Norma Leticia tiene ya más D. 2 años con su negocio D. venta D. ropa usada y nueva. Este negocio es L. fuente D. ingresos D. mi familia. El negocio lo tengo fuera D. mi casa esto es para no descuidar a mis tres hijos que tengo. Pero me esta haciendo falta mas mercancía y nueva para vender ya que mis clientas me están pidiendo ciertos modelos D. ropa. Solicito un préstamo D. $1,200 Dlls Para L. comprar D. mercancía nueva y D. mejor calidad.

loans.use: To Buy New Merchandise for My Business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Miguel Roberto

texts.en:
I have been renting and selling business suits for more than three years. This business is the source of income for my family. I need a machine and more modern equipment for more elaborate tailoring of the suits, and also I would like to rent a separate space because right now, I operate this business out of my home. It would be nice to have the two separate. I am asking for a loan of $750.00 to purchase a machine and equipment for tailoring and for rental space in the center of the city of Nuevo Laredo, Mexico.

Translated from Spanish by Jenny Dean, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo ya más de 3 años con el negocio de venta y renta de trajes para caballeros. Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de mi familia. En el negocio me esta haciendo falta una maquina y equipo mas moderno para la elaboración de los trajes, también quiero rentar un local ya que lo tengo el negocio en mi casa quiero separar el negocio de la casa. Solicitó un préstamo de $750.00 Dlls. Para la compra de maquina y equipo de trabajo de costura y la renta de un local en el centro de la cuidad de Nuevo Laredo Mexico.

loans.use: To Buy a Machine and Equipment for Tailoring

loans.name: Sareourn

texts.en: Mrs. Sareourn Y. is a farmer who has worked in the fields nearly all her life. She is 60 years old and the mother of two children. Her husband, Eourn Sun, works as a farmer with her. Both of them usually earn $7 a day by selling vegetables in a local market. She asks for a loan so that she can buy more crop seeds, to grow a more diverse crop, and thus increase her business in the market.

loans.use: To buy more crop seed to grow crops.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. Pov C. has more than ten year's sewing experience, and she presently is looking for additional work. She makes about $1.50 a day. She is 36 years old and is married, with five children. Her husband, Hou Thok, is a moto-taxi driver in a local village and he can earn about $3 a day. Additionally, the two own a rice field, and Mrs. Pov  requests a loan to buy two cows to work on it.

loans.use: To buy two cows for work on her rice field.

loans.name: Eourn

texts.en: Cambodia is mostly agricultural, and most Cambodians are farmers. Mrs. Eourn K. dedicates herself as a farmer in the Kandal province; she is 57 years old and she is married with a child who works in a garment factory, where she earns about $2 a day. Mrs. Eourn earns only $1.50 a day. Mr. Toch Chan, Eourn's husband, is a fisherman and makes an income of about $4 a day. She is now asking for a loan to hire a laborer to plow her rice field, and purchase more fertilizer to support the field.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to plow the field and buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Mrs. Chan T., 70, is a widow and works as a rice dealer in her village. She sells rice, and resells it for profit, earning on average $4 a day. She has four children, two who are married and live in their own homes. One child works in a hotel with a salary $280 and one other daughter works with her mother selling rice. She would like to borrow $1000 to increase the amount of rice she can buy in bulk and resell. This will increase her profit margin. (The elder daughter is pictured because Mrs. Chan T. was not available).

loans.use: She wants to purchase rice in bulk.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Mrs. Touch P. is a 37-year-old widow and sells roasted chickens from her house in the Koki Village in the Kompong Svey Commune in Banteay Meanchey Province. She has seven children, all of whom are single and earn about $5 a day. One child sells ice at Thmey Market, another is a worker in Nek Meas restaurant. Because of her business, she now can pay for her family’s living expenses and make sure her children can go to school.

To help her business, she is asking for a loan of $400 to decorate her house to be an attractive place in which to sell roasted chickens. She thanks Kiva for their support and promises to be prompt in repaying her loan.

loans.use: To decorate her house to be an attractive place in which to sell roasted chickens.

payments.comment: Mrs. Touch Pov has successfully paid off her loan well ahead of schedule.

loans.name: Ravshanbek

texts.en:
B. Ravshanbek is a 22-year-old farmer. He has been working the land since he was fifteen. Ravshanbek grows onions and maize. When it is the season, Ravshanbek works in the fields from the early morning until the late night.

Five years ago, Ravshanbek started producing onions on a plot of 0.10 hectares (1/4 acre). Currently, he grows onions on 0.50 hectares (1.24 acres) and wheat on 0.50 hectares (1.24 acres) of land. Now, when the business is stable, Ravshanbek believes that it shall be the main income for him in future.

Today, Ravshanbek is applying for a loan for the first time. He requests 2000.00 Somoni ($600.00 USD) for 7 months. Ravshanbek is planning to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and combustive-lubricating materials. He will also use the part of the loan to pay the salaries of seasonal workers. Ravshanbek thanks everyone who trusts him by supporting him today. He promises to pay back the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer, combustive-lubricating materials, and to pay the salaries of seasonal workers.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 39942

loans.name: Farhod

texts.en:
B. Farhod is 37 years old. He is married with three children. Farhod runs a farm. On the part of his plot, he is grows onion and maize. Farhod is an experienced farmer; he has worked the land for the last 10 years. The business is stable and generates his main income. 

However, this business requires lots of effort and supplies. So, now Farhod needs to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and fuel. He also needs funds to pay the salaries of seasonal workers. That is why Farhod is requesting 2000.00 Somoni ($600.00 USD) for the term of 7 months. Farhod thanks all for supporting him, and throughout the term of this, his first loan, he promises to be accurate when paying the loan.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer, and fuel, and to pay the salaries of seasonal workers.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 39943

loans.name: Preap

texts.en: Mrs. Preap Y., 44, is married with 3 children and works as a farmer. She grows rice, earning $3 a day. Her husband is in the army at Siem Reap province, Cambodia. Normally, he makes around $1.50 a day. One of their children is a construction worker, and the other is a security worker, who works at Phnom Penh city. They earn an average of about $1 each per day. Preap needs a loan to purchase a motorbike for her commute to work. Previously, Preap Y. rode a bicycle to her field, and that is difficult because her house and the farm land is far away. To make transportation easier and to save time, she decided to ask for a loan from Kiva to buy a motorbike. (She took a picture with her husband and the motorbike she wants to buy behind them.)

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.name: Bahtier

texts.en:
C. Bahtier is 31 years old. He is married with three kids.

Bahtier is a market vender. In the central local market, Bahtier sells sweets and candies. He has been in this business for more than fourteen years. Bahtier's wife, who appears in the accompanying photograph, helps her husband sell goods in the market. For all 14 years, Bahtier has managed to make his business successful and to generate a stable income for his family, allowing Bahtier to improve their living conditions.

Today, Bahtier is planning to expand his business by purchasing more sweets and candies in order to increase the range of goods for selling. For this purpose, he requests $1000 USD for a term of 6 months. Bahtier has taken a loan from International MicroLoan Fund (IMON) before, and has proved himself to be a reliable client. Now, he promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all for their support.

loans.use: Purchasing of the sweets in order to increase the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Umed

texts.en:
C. Umed is 19 years old. Despite his young age, Umed has already been running his business for three years. Umed sells accessories for cell phones like chargers, earphones, and cell phone cases. The business is located in the central local market.

Umed manages his business successfully and there is a strong trend for development of this business in future. Now, Umed is planning to expand his business and purchase more cell phone accessories to sell. For this purpose, he is requesting $1000.00 USD for the term of 6 months. Umed has already taken a loan and proved himself to be a reliable client. He promises to repay the current loan in time and thanks all for their support.

loans.use: To buy cell phone accessories to increase the range of goods for sale

loans.name: Jhem

texts.en: Mrs. Jhem T., 49, sells vegetables in a busy market making about $1 a day. Her husband stays at home, growing a variety of vegetables on a plot of land that earns about $3 a day. They have eight children: three are garment workers, and two sons work as security guards in Phnom Penh with a salary $60 each per month. Three of the other children stay at home and help the father with his farming. He wants a loan from Kiva to hire people to dig an irrigation system, to make watering more efficient, especially during droughts. Moreover, this money will be used to purchase fertilizers to help grow vegetables.

loans.use: To dig an irrigation system and purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Askar

texts.en:
Turdimurotov Askar is 45 years old. He and his wife are raising two children.

Askar breeds cattle and sheep. Askar started his business in 2004, when he sold 2 sheep. Today, Askar's business has strongs trend for development. He buys and raises cows and sheep, and then sells them at the local market. Because his business is the main source of income for his family, Askar works hard to keep the business stable and successful.

After four years in business, this is the first time Askar has applied for the loan. He requests 2000.00 Somoni ($600.00 USD) for a term of 12 months. With the loan money, he will buy a cow. Askar would like thank everyone for their trust. He promises to be precise in his loan payments.

loans.use: To buy a cow

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for International MicroLoan Fund (IMON), a partner of Mercy Corps - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Gulom

texts.en:
Turdimurotov Gulom is 26 years old. He is married and has an adorable 2-year-old son.

Gulom raises and sells cattle. After purchasing the cattle in the local market, he raises them at home. Four years ago, when Gulom made the decision to raise cattle, he constructed a cow shed. Now he has four cows to sell for $2,000 USD. The business is stable and generates the main income for the family, allowing Gulom to improve their living conditions.

Now Gulom is planning to purchase one more cow. For this purpose, he requests 2000.00 Somoni ($600.00 USD). For this first loan, Gulom is grateful to all for trusting and supporting him, and he promises to pay back the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To buy a cow to raise and sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for International MicroLoan Fund (IMON), a partner of Mercy Corps - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Mrs. Sorn S., 47, is a mother of 7 children and also owns a plot of farmland with her husband. They grow a variety of vegetables, earning $4 a day. Four of their children are married and live separately. Three others stay at home and help them on the farm. To grow more fruit and vegetables, they need a loan from Kiva to purchase a water pump and fertilizers to put on the crops. Moreover, this money will be used to buy rice to keep for the next year (rice to cook).

loans.use: To purchase a water pump and fertilizers.

loans.name: Arm

texts.en: Mrs. Arm C., 29, works selling firewood in her village and earns $2 a day of profit. Her husband supplements the household income by working as a boat worker, making about $2 a day. They have no children. To increase sales of firewood, she needs a loan from Kiva to purchase a horse cart to transfer wood to sell to another village. (Her picture is taken when she in the CREDIT office.)

loans.use: To purchase a horse cart to transfer wood to sell to another village, to increase profits.

loans.name: Malika

texts.en: Malika G. is married and has 5 children.  She has been one of the active clients of MicroInvest since 2003.  She applied for a business development loan, improved her business and then opened a material sales outlet. She has a wide assortment of materials.  She is now applying for a KIVA loan of 2100 STJ for 6 months to purchase new seasonal goods.

loans.use: To purchase new seasonal goods

loans.name: Chanuka Support Group

texts.en:
Chanuka Support Group was formed on 1st May 2005 with six founding members, namely:

1. Janet O. Achola.

2. Samuel O. N..

3. Selline J. O..

4. Hyrene a. O..

5. Lucas a. Odera.

6. Clarice O. Oluoch.

The above founding six members came together on issues and matters affecting their lives.

They came together with an aim of assisting each other and also contributing money to pay for members' transport to attend clinical services at Chulaimbo Rural Provincial Health Centre. As time went by the group registered more members and now has 45 members. The members have also been trained by K-MET in Nutrition support, Home Based Care services, and IGAs management.

The group is run by executives comprised of the Chairperson, Secretary, Assistant Secretary, Organizing Secretary, and the Treasurer. Members wishing to join the group are required to pay a fee which helps them run the day-to-day affairs of the group. A number of members have well-established income-generating activities such as poultry farming, dairy farming, cereal businesses, vegetable stalls, and community pharmacies. Since HIV/Aids is a concern in this area and good nutrition has played a major role in HIV/Aids management, the group through K-MET has applied for US $5000 to enable them purchase Nutriflour in bulk to sell to the locals around and beyond the community.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Buy Nutriflour in bulk for sale to the community.

loans.name: Meong

texts.en: Mrs. Meong D., 31, has a business with her husband selling groceries, gas, and ice at their house, earning around $20 a day in revenue. They have two children, one of whom just recently started school. She would like to request a loan from Kiva to purchase groceries in bulk to lower the cost of purchase, as now she has many customers.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for her business.

loans.name: Maksuda

texts.en: Maksuda M. lives in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan. She is not married but has 2 children. She trades different sorts of materials and angora wool.  She works directly with the suppliers and her prices are lower than the that of the bazaar. She has a wide assortment and repeat customers.  She is now requesting a KIVA business development loan of 1600 STJ for 7 months for business expansion.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Om

texts.en: Mrs. Om Y., 46, is married with six children and works selling groceries at her house, earning around $7 a day in revenue. Her husband supports the family as a farmer,. He grows rice and makes on average $2.50 a day. Two children are employed by a garment factory in Phnom Penh city with a salary $70 each a month. Two others are waiters, and the rest of the children stay at home helping their parents with their work. To make the business grow, Om decided to appeal for a loan from Kiva to purchase more grocery products. With the rest, they will use it in the side business of raising pigs for additional income. This will give the family a more stable income.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products, and also to raise pigs for additional income.

loans.name: Gavharoy

texts.en: K. Gavharoy is a 37 year old; married and has 3 children. She lives in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan and trades in the local bazaar in household wares.  She trades goods that are manufactured in China.  She also has a business selling children's clothes. She has been running her business for 5 years.  She is applying to KIVA for a business development loan of 2600 STJ for 8 months.  She would like to use the funds to increase her assortment of goods and attract new customers.

loans.use: to wide the existing assortment of goods to attract new customers

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 36 years old and is a married woman with two children, ages 15 and 10 years old. She and her husband also take care of one other older person, aged 65 years old.

Lucy owns a small salon, which she began running in 2005. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Jamila's Tupendane Group

texts.en:
Jamila is 46 years old and is a married woman with three children; they are 32, 20 and 11 years old. She and her husband also take care of one other elderly person who is 80 years old.

Jamila owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and earns an average monthly profit of $25 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Kagali East B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jennifer M.. She is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to increase her inventory. Jennifer is 47 years old and is married. She has 5 children ranging from age 6 to 19 and her children go to school. Each week, Jennifer makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy building materials.

Jennifer is joined in her small group by Sarah O., Loy M., Mangdalene N., and Harriet A.. Sarah O. has a business running a restaurant and wants to add equipment. Loy M. is currently operating a business selling jack-fruit and wants a loan to boost business. Mangdalene N. operates a business selling fish and wants to invest in her business. Harriet A. is currently in the business selling fish and is requesting a loan to add capital.

loans.use: To purchase large quantities of clothes

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en: M. Mavluda has been the client of the MicroInvest since 2007 but she has recommended herself as a serious and executive client that trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure. She is married and has 4 children. She is engaged in selling household goods. She is very polite and has a lot of clients.  She is now applying for a business development loan of 2100 STJ for 9 months for opening a trade outlet in the local bazaar.

loans.use: For opening a trade outlet in the local bazaar

loans.name: Kagali East C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Joyce W.. She is currently in the business of clothing sales and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Joyce is 42 years old and is married. She has 8 children ranging from age 6 to 21 and her children go to school. Each week, Joyce makes approximately UGX 15000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to invest in her business. Joyce has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Joyce is joined in her small group by Anna N., Deborah M., Priska T., and Teresa W.. Anna N. has a business trading produce and wants to boost business. Deborah M. is currently operating a business selling bread and wants a loan to increase capital. Priska T. operates a business selling soft drinks and wants to purchase a fridge. Teresa W. is currently in the business of clothing sales and is requesting a loan to add stock.

loans.use: To boost and expand clothing business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Bahati's Tupendane Group

texts.en:
Bahati is 26 years old and is married woman with one child, aged two years old. Bahati owns a small food vendor store and kiosk, which she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $15 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Joyce, who has a business dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Kagali East D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Efransi N.. She is currently in the business of selling matooke and is requesting a loan to purchase in bulk. Efransi is 23 years old and is divorced. She has 2 children aged 3 and 5, and both of her children go to school. Each week, Efransi makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land.

Efransi is joined in her small group by Kauma N., Halima N., Mariam N., and Flora O.. Kauma N. has a business in clothing sales and wants to increase her inventory. Halima N. is currently operating a business selling tomatoes and wants a loan to put up a stall. Mariam N. operates a retail shop business and wants to add more items. Flora O. is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to add more furniture.

loans.use: To add to matooke business

loans.name: Roziya

texts.en: M. Roziya lives in the J.Rasuov region; she is married and has 5 children.  She is in the business of pastry and confectionery selling.  She always has a wide assortment of freshly-baked pastries. Now she would like to apply for a KIVA business development loan of 3600 STJ for 9 months to import new goods and further increase her assortment.

loans.use: Increase assortment of inventory and to import more goods

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mrs. San K., 47, is a mother of 9 children and works selling fish in a busy market, normally earning about $3 a day. Her husband, who is a farmer, makes on average $2 a day of profit. They have 9 children: two are garment workers making a salary of $60 each a month. Two others are painters and make an average of $2 each per day. The others stay at home to help their parents work.

The loan will be used to purchase more fish to sell in the market.

loans.use: To purchase more fish.

loans.name: Adina's Jishughulishe Group

texts.en:
Adina is 30 years old and is a married woman with two children, ages 13 and seven years old. Adina is a cloth seller; she started this business in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $15 from her sales.

She now hopes to receive a loan so that she can purchase more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in salon and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Kagali East E Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Suzan N.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to buy more fabric and thread. Suzan is 39 years old and is divorced. She has 4 children ranging from age 3 to 20 and her children go to school. Each week, Suzan makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy building materials.

Suzan is joined in her small group by Madina N., Esther M., Rose B., and Josephine N.. Madina N. has a business running a restaurant and wants to add utensils and saucepans. Esther M. is currently operating a business selling clothes and wants a loan to purchase in bulk. Rose B. operates a business selling clothes and wants to add to her business. Josephine N. is currently in the business of selling fish and is requesting a loan to expand business.

loans.use: To add working capital to tailoring business

loans.name: Gulandom

texts.ru:
Gulandom K. lives in the Shahrinav region. She is married and has 2 children. She has a High School education and is a stay at home mom. She is also in the business of growing potatoes. She has a piece of land on which her family plants potatoes. Most of the obtained crop is sold on the market while a small portion is kept to provide for the family. She plans to use the loan to purchase potato seeds and fertilizer in time for the potato planting season. Gulandom's business provides her family and the local markets with potatoes. She plans to repay the loan withing a 15 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Караева Гуландом проживает в районе Шахринау. Замужем , имеет двоих детей. Образование среднее. Домохозяйка. Занимается сельским хозяйством имеет участок земли который засеивает картофелем.Полученный урожай использует как для своей семьи так и для продажи.Планирует получить кредит для того чтобы закупить семена картофеля и удобрения, так как сейчас сезон посева картофеля.Этот кредит поможет клиентке вовремя засеить картофель , тем самым обеспечив свою семью и рынки картофелем. Погасить кредит клиентка планирует в течении 15 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase potato seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Shabana's Group

texts.en:
I am Shabana I. from the small, lush green town Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan. I was married five years ago and have one son who is three years old. I plan to send him to the best school in the town, so that he can become a good citizen and can also find good jobs.

My husband used to be a daily wage laborer and now he does farming. To farm, we have rented land and raise pumpkins and mustard in it. I do not go out to work, because it is not considered acceptable in the society in which I live, but I take care of two cows at my house.

I am borrowing to buy another dairy cow. My group members are Parween B., whose husband is a local transport driver; Nargis H. and Razia B., both of whom are borrowing for their husbands, who sell fruit from a cart; and Mariam B., who will use the loan to buy a dairy cow.

loans.use: Buy a dairy cow

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Manka's Ujirani Mwema Group

texts.en:
Manka is 25 years old and is single woman. She takes care of two other people, ages 27 and 12 years old. Manka owns a small food shop, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of approximately $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in animal keeping and cloth selling.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Namayemba East A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rofina O.. She is currently in the business of buying and selling produce and is requesting a loan to add capital. Rofina is 42 years old and is married. She has 6 children ranging from age 8 to 21 and her children go to school. Each week, Rofina makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to invest in her business. Rofina has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Rofina is joined in her small group by Demintiria E., Yunusu N., Fatina T., and Joan K.. Demintiria E. has a business running a retail shop and wants to purchase a fridge. Yunusu N. is currently operating a business selling fish and wants a loan to add more business. Fatina T. operates a restaurant business and wants to purchase more raw food. Joan K. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add more stock.

loans.use: To purchase and sell produce in large quantities

loans.name: Marietha

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 47-year-old Marietha M.. She is married with 4 children, aged 13, 17, 21, and 22.

In 2002 Marietha established a food stall and charcoal business. Working 9 to 12 hours a day, 6 days a week, she earns about $175 per month from this business. Marietha has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from SELFINA, and she now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stocks of fruit, vegetables, and charcoal in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $260. In the future, Marietha also plans to employ more staff, renovate her shop, and increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of charcoal, fruits, and vegetables

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Bahodur

texts.ru:
Bahodur Padjabolievich J. lives in teh Shahrinav region in Tajikistan. He is 30 years old, married and has 6 children. He has a High School education and works as a farmer. He has a piece of land on which he grows potatoes. He sells most of the crop on the market and keeps a small portion of it to provide for his family. The profit from this business allows him to provide for his family as well as to purchase seeds and fertilizer for next year. He plans to use the obtained loan to purchase high quality seeds and fertilizer. He plans to repay the loan within a 12 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Джумаев Баходур Раджаболиевич проживает в районе Шахринау. Возраст 30 лет, женат. Имеет 6 детей. Имеет среднее образование.Занимается земледелием. Имеет дехканское хозяйство. Засеивает землю картофелем. Получаемый урожай использует для своей семьи и большую часть продает на рынке. Это дает доход для его семьи, часть которой он использует на жизнь , а остальную часть для посева в новом сезоне. Планирует получить кредит для того чтобы закупить качественные семена и удобрения. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase potato seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Asiah's Group

texts.en:
I am a widow named Asiah H.. I live in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan, with my five children, three boys and two girls. One girl is married and one boy works at a local factory, while all others attend school. I sew clothes on order from my neighborhood clients and also run a small grocery store. I work very hard so that I can continue sending my children to school.

I plan to buy a stock of various items for my store and require a loan for this purpose. I am a group leader of few other women who are my neighbors and I completely trust them. These women are: Fatima A., whose husband sells shoes and cloth, Parween Y., who will invest her share of loan in her husband’s tractor, and Barkat B., who wants to buy a cow.

loans.use: Buy a stock of various items for the store

loans.name: Anthonia

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 58-year-old Anthonia S.. She is widowed with 4 children, aged between 21 and 36, and has 2 other dependents, who live with her because they are orphans.

In 2002 Anthonia established a clothing business. Working 5 to 8 hours a day, 6 days a week, and assisted by her 1 employee, she earns about $80 per month from this business. Anthonia now requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of clothing and African cloth. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $35. In the future, Anthonia also plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of clothing and African batik cloth

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Namayemba East B Group

texts.en:

Florence is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is a dry cleaner for work. She has 7 children ranging from age 6 to 16 and her children go to school. Each week, Florence makes approximately UGX 150000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to invest in her business. Florence has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Florence is joined in her small group by Rose B., Florence N., Loy E., and Mikani O.. Rose B. has a business running a salon and wants to purchase a hair dryer. Florence N. is currently operating a restaurant business and wants a loan to buy food warmers. Loy E. operates a business selling tomatoes and wants to increase her inventory. Mikani O. is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to add more equipment.

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Mrs. Em Y., 61, works with her husband on a plot of land growing rice and vegetables, earning around $2 a day of profit. They have 3 children: one is married and lives away from home, and the other two help their parents growing rice and vegetables.

This loan will be used to purchase a water pump, fertilizers, and good rice seed to assist in their work.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump, fertilizers, and good rice seed.

Bobokalon Tilakovich Bekmyrodov lives in the Shahrinav region in Tajikistan. He is 56 years old, married and has 9 children. He has a High School education and works as a farmer. He has a piece of land on which he grows potatoes. He sells most of the obtained crop on the market and keeps a small portion of it to provide for his family. The profit from the business allows him to take care of his family and purchase seeds and fertilizer for next year. He plans to use the obtained loan to purchase high quality seeds and fertilizer. He plans to repay the loan within a 12 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Бекмуродов Бобокалон Тилакович проживает в районе Шахринау. Возраст 56 лет, женат. Имеет 9 детей.Имеет среднее образование.Занимается земледелием. Имеет дехканское хозяйство. Засеивает землю картофелем. Получаемый урожай использует для своей семьи и большую часть продает на рынке. Это дает доход для его семьи, часть которой он использует на жизнь , а остальную часть для посева в новом сезоне. Планирует получить кредит для того чтобы закупить качественные семена и удобрения. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase potato seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Sabina S.. She is married with 3 children, aged 5, 8, and 12.

Sabina owns a general store, where she works 13 to 16 hours a day, 6 days a week. Sabina now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $85. In the future, Sabina also plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of soft drinks, tea, soap, rice, and oil in bulk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Kalsoom's Group

texts.en:
I am Kalsoom A. R., the leader of a small group of women. They include Safia A., who needs this loan for their fruit business. Nawab B. is borrowing for her brother, who sells construction supplies. Rasheeda R. will use the loan to expand their fruit business. Ayesha B. is a widow and she is borrowing for her son who operates a billiard centre.

I live in Kot Radha Kishan, a small town in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of seven. All of my children are married and live separately. My children could not attend school because of our very poor economic conditions. My husband has operated a fruit shop since his teens. Earlier, he used to sell fruit from a cart, but after acquiring three continuous loans from Asasah, a microfinance institute, we have now shifted our fruit business into a shop. I used to stitch clothes, but I do not sew any more. I request you to help all of us so that we can further improve our lives.

loans.use: Expand fruit business

loans.name: Namayemba East C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Joy N.. She is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to boost business. Joy is 34 years old and is married. She has 5 children ranging from age 4 to 13 and her children go to school. Each week, Joy makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. Joy has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Joy is joined in her small group by Rose A., Florence O., Umice A., and Beatrice A.. Rose A. has a business selling clothes and wants to add more capital. Florence O. is currently operating a business in shoe sales and wants a loan to purchase more shoes to sell. Umice A. operates a business selling charcoal and wants to increase her inventory. Beatrice A. is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to buy more furniture.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and increase stock

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Mrs. Kim S., 55, is a widow who sells hand bags in a busy market in Phnom Penh city and earns on average $10 a day. She has 3 children, two are students and one helps her selling hand bags in the market.

This money she will use to purchase hand bags in bulk for a cost savings and also to meet the customer’s demand. She sell hand bags in Toul Tompong market, or the Russian market, where most of the foreigners visiting Cambodia spend their time looking for a good souvenirs.

loans.use: To purchase hand bags in bulk.

loans.name: Nezia

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 50-year-old Nezia L.. She is single and has 7 children.

In 2002 Nezia established a clothing business. Nezia now requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of clothing in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To expand her range of clothing

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Pea

texts.en:
Mr. Pea B., 38, drives a soil truck and earns up to $4 a day. His wife, Mrs. Loch Sary, is a grocer in the Russey Krok District in Bateay Meanchey Province and earns about $5 a day. Pea B. has three children, all of whom are still young. 

To earn a living for the family, B. is now requesting a loan of $800 to increase inventory of groceries for his wife’s business, so Sary can efficiently customer demand. He thanks Kiva for their support and promises to be accurate and faithful in his loan payment.

loans.use: To increase inventory of groceries for his wife's business

loans.name: Namayemba East D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Grace A.. She is currently in the business of buying and selling produce and is requesting a loan to increase her purchases. Grace is 32 years old and is married. She has 2 children aged 4 and 7, and both of her children go to school. Each week, Grace makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy building materials. Grace has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Grace is joined in her small group by Veronica N., Zaria Biribawa, Ali K., and Grace A.. Veronica N. has a business selling fish and wants to re-invest in her business. Zaria Biribawa is currently operating a business selling matooke and wants a loan to expand to bulk selling. Ali K. operates a restaurant business and wants to purchase more utensils and raw food. Grace A. is currently in the business of selling fish and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To add working capital to produce business

loans.name: Namayemba East D Group

texts.en:

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Monica M.. She is married with 2 children, aged 4 and 9, and has 1 other dependent, who is her nephew.

In 2006 Monica established a used clothing business, and she now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stocks of clothing in bulk.

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and they are then washed, ironed, and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because they are so cheap and because of the general appeal of anything Western or modern. Many people argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress; however, the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of used clothing in bulk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Nabwike

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 23-year-old Nabwike S.. In 2006 Nabwike established a poultry business, and she now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional chicks to raise and sell. She thanks you for your support.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. In fact, if you are a regular lender on kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku. Who or what are ‘kuku,’ you may ask. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons.

First, they require little start-up capital; you can start with 1 or 2 and either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiply naturally! Second, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Third, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. I’m sure there are hundreds of other reasons why raising kuku is so popular (maybe they are friendlier than other animals or prettier?), but this is all time and space will allow.

loans.use: To purchase additional chicks to raise and sell

loans.name: Ashura

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 44-year-old Ashura L.. She is married with 4 children, aged between 14 and 23.

In 2007 Ashura established a café business, and she now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional ingredients, such as rice, oil, flour, and beans, in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café,’ you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot, sticky dough made from maize flour), and plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients, such as rice, oil, beans, and fish, in bulk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Ahror.

texts.ru:
Ahror M. lives in the Shahrinav region. He is 45 years old, is married and has 5 children. Ahror has a high school education, he raises small livestock that he then sells for meat. He purchases livestock at the regional market, feeds it for 30-40 days and then sells it for a profit. He has been in this business for 15 years. This business is the main source of income for his family. In addition, the expansion of the livestock business provides local markets with fresh meat. Ahror will use his loan to purchase young sheep and goats. He will pay back the loan over a 6 months period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Малаев Ахрор Умарович проживает в районе Шахринау.Возраст 45 лет . Женат имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается животноводством. Разводит мелко-рогатый скот для перепродажи их на мясо. Покупает товар на рынке района, откармливает около 30-40 дней , а затем перепродает по более выгодной цене. Занимается этим видом бизнеса клиент уже 15 лет. Этот бизнес является основным источником дохода его семьи. Кроме того развитие данного сектора позволяет обеспечивать рынки свежим мясом.Клиент хочет получить кредит для того чтобы закупить молодых овец и коз. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 6 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase small livestock

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 59-year-old Mwajuma K.. She is single with 2 children, aged 29 and 34.

In 2007 Mwajuma established a grocery store business. Mwajuma has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from SELFINA, and she now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her grocery store

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Gazihan

texts.ru:
Gazihan Gajaliev was born and continues to live in the Agsu region. He was born in 1958. he is married and has 4 children. His whole family is involved in one business – raising livestock. They have been in this business for 10 years. Gazihan has plans to grow his family business with the help of this loan. Gazihan applied for a loan to Normicro, Agsu branch.

Translated from Russian by Jamilya & Keith Leitich, Kiva Volunteers

Гаджалыев Газыхан родился и проживает в Ахсуниском районе. 1958 года рождения. Семейный. Имеет четверых детей. Вся семья занимается одним бизнесом,скотоводством. Десять лет не прошло даром. Но в этом остановливатся он не собирается. Нужен кредит чтобы расширятся. Газыхан обратился в Нормикро Ахсуниский филиал.

loans.use: To increase the guantity of animals

loans.name: Subhonkul

texts.ru:
Subhonkul Komilovich K. lives in the Shahrinov region. He is 21 and is single. He has a secondary education. Subhonkul buys seeds of pototoes and sells them at the local market to both private customers and agriculture enterprises. Subhonkul buys seeds wholesale , paying lower prices and then he resells them at lower then usual prices. It allows the local population to purchase potato seeds at affordable prices. This business is the main source of income for Subhonkul. He plans to use the proceeds of his loan to increase his turnover. It will allow him to attract more customers and increase his profits. He is planning to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Jamilya & Keith Leitich, Kiva Volunteers

Кенджаев Субхонкул Комилович проживает в районе Шахринау. Возраст 21 год, холост. Имеет среднее образование.Занимается предпринимательством в сфере сельхоз продукции. Завозит в район семена картофеля отборных сортов и реализует у себя на рынке частным покупателям , а так же аграрным хозяйствам.Так как клиент скупает товар у оптовых реализаторов по оптовым ценам и реализует оптовым покупателям так же по более низкой цене. Это позволяет населению приобретать картофель по доступным ценам. Кроме того этот бизнес является основным источником дохода его семьи. Клиент планирует получить кредит для того чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Это поможет увеличить объем продаваемой продукции, что даст возможность увеличить количество клиентов, а так же увеличить доход. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase turnover

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Huram

texts.ru:
Huram Umarovich M. lives in the Shahrinov region. He is 42 and is married with 4 children. He has a secondary education. He is involved in animal husbandry. He raises livestock and then sells them. He buys young animals at the regional market, feeds them for 30-40 days and then sells then at a higher price. Huram has been in this business for 14 years. This business is the main source of his family’s income. The development of his business allows Huram to supply local market with fresh meat. Huram wants to receive a loan to purchase young sheep and goats. He plans to repay his loan within 6 months.

Покупает товар на рынке района, откармливает около 30-40 дней , а затем перепродает по более выгодной цене. Занимается этим видом бизнеса клиент уже 14 лет. Этот бизнес является основным источником дохода его семьи. Кроме того развитие данного сектора позволяет обеспечивать рынки свежим мясом.Клиент хочет получить кредит для того чтобы закупить молодых овец и коз. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 6 месяцев.

loans.name: Kamu Kamu Development Group

texts.en: 42 year old Kate is the chairperson of Kamu kamu development group. She is married with 4 kids and cares for another 4 of her late sister’s children. She has been operating a retail shop in Kangulumira for 8 years and has been our client for 4 years. Her dream is to transform her retail shop into whol sale as well as buy a plot and build commercial houses. She plans to buy more Colgate, sugar, Vaseline for the shop and buy more broiler chicken since this has been her side business for a year. Kate is really hardworking and dedicated.

loans.use: To buy more Colgate, sugar, Vaseline for the shop and buy more broiler chicken as a side business.

loans.name: Zimula Josephine's Group

texts.en: Josephine, the leader of her group has a retail shop in Mbiko that has been operational for one year. The group has been together for 1 year and so far no regrets. She is single with no children but cares for her 5 year old neice in primary one. She plans to expand her shop by buying more sugar, soap, washing powder, bread so that she can be able to buy a plot and build a house. Her dream is to get married and see her shop transform into a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap, washing powder, bread, biscuits, plus other goods for her shop.

loans.name: Uyigue

texts.en:
Uyigue A. is married with 4 children. She is 42 years old. She is from Edo State, Nigeria.

Uyigue sells provisions and drinks to earn a living. She has been in business since 2004. She needs the loan of $525 to buy more provisions and drinks for sale.

loans.name: Magirane Oliver's Group

texts.en: Oliver together with her group members are requesting a loan to run their various businesses. Oliver has a retail shop in Wabusanke that she has owned for 2 years. She has 6 children that she cares for single handedly after her husband left her for another woman. Her dream is to see all her children complete school and get good jobs in future since they are all still in school. She intends to buy a fridge for her shop so that she can sell cold drinks in addition to the other goods like sugar, salt, bread, and biscuits.

texts.en:

To make akpu, cassava is soaked in water for days. When it is fermented, it is filtered and the resulting content is squeezed, cooked for 30 minutes, and tied in a small nylon for sale.) Elizabeth needs the loan of $600 to buy more cassava and firewood for sale.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and cassava for sale

Emmanuel has been in business for the past 6 years. He needs the loan of $700 to buy another bike.

loans.name: Victoria

loans.name: Suzan Evan

texts.en:

This is a group loan and the funds will be distributed among the group members. Each member will invest her loan in her own or in her family's business.

loans.name: Elizbeth's Group

texts.en:

I own a three-room cement/brick house here in Chichawatni. I have four kids: one boy and three girls. All my kids are below 14 years of age and study at a good local school. I am a women's health worker and provide health services to the inhabitants of my community. I work very hard to provide a better living for my family. I need a loan to buy few medical instruments.

I am a group leader for a few other women who are also in need of loans. They are: Shahnaz A. requires loan to buy a donkey cart; Zahida T. will invest her share of the loan in her family’s motorbikes business; Nazia is borrowing to improve their video games centre and Sajida S. needs loan to fix their rickshaw.

loans.name: Essavi

texts.fr:
Essavi W. was born on September 24, 1953 in Treichville (Republic of Cote d'Ivoire).  She is married and the mother of two, and she lives with her husband, Victor d’ALMEIDA, who is employed at the DGI (the department of revenue).  This is her second loan, and her main business is commerce in pagnes (colorful print fabrics) at the Grand Market in Lomé, where she started in 2005.  She buys pagnes from wholesalers and displays them for sale.  Having increased her working capital through her first loan of 350,000 francs CFA that she has by the way repaid promptly, she has increased her profits while meeting customer needs.  The loan of 500,000 francs CFA that she is requesting should enable her to serve her customers better by acquiring 30 bolts of GTP-brand pagnes.  She can then create a new retail outlet in order to improve her sales.  
 Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Madame W. Essavi est née le 24 Septembre 1953 à Treichville (République de Côte d’Ivoire). Mariée et mère de 2 enfants, elle vit avec son mari dénommé d’ALMEIDA Victor employé à la DGI (Direction Générale des Impôts).Elle est à son deuxième crédit et son activité principale est le commerce de  pagne au Grand Marché de Lomé qu’elle a débutée en 2005 . Elle achète chez les grossistes et les dispose en étalage. 
Ayant augmenté son fonds de roulement à travers son premier crédit de 350000 f cfa qu’elle a d’ailleurs promptement remboursé, elle a amélioré son bénéfice en satisfaisant les besoins de sa clientèle.
Le crédit qu’elle sollicite d’un montant de 500000 f cfa devait lui permettre de mieux servir ses clients à travers l’achat de  30 pièces de pagne de marque GTP pour la création d’un nouveau de point de vente en vue d’améliorer ses ventes.

By selling clothes, Borka wants to improve her  monthly income.  She wants to  secure money for her son's school fees.

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 46 year old Rhoda M.. She is single with two children, age five and eight. She also has one other dependent, who is her nephew.

In 2007, Rhoda established a poultry business. She has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan to purchase additional chicks to raise and sell. She thanks you for your support.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. In fact, if you are a regular lender on kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku. Who or what are kuku, you may ask. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons.

Firstly, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two and then either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiple naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. I’m sure there are hundreds of other reasons why raising kuku is so popular--maybe they are friendlier than other animals or prettier--but this is all time and space will allow.

loans.use: To purchase more chicks to raise and sell

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is Eva M., who is married with three children, age four, fourteen, and twenty-one.

In 1996, Eva established a business selling fresh vegetables. She now requires a loan to purchase more stock of vegetables in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of vegetables in bulk

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella A. is married with 4 children. She is 43 years old and hails from Edo State, Nigeria.

Stella sells provisions and foodstuffs in her store. She has been in business for 12 years. Stella needs a loan in the amount of $525 to buy more provisions and foodstuffs for her store.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 43 year old Halima K.. She is married with two children, ages twelve and fifteen.

In 1991, Halima established an African batik cloth business. She has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA. She requires a new loan to purchase cloth and dyes, which she will use to make additional stock of batik cloth for sale. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase cloth and dyes to make African batik material

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 34 year old Flora N.. She is married with three children, aged nine, twelve, and thirteen. She also has two other dependents, who are her nieces.

In 2000, Flora established a clothing business. She requires a loan to purchase additional stock of clothing in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase clothing in bulk to sell

loans.name: Jenifa

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 43 year old Jenifa S.. She is single with two children, ages 18 and 22.

In 2004, Jenifa established a hair salon business. Hair, hair and more hair! This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, or blue hair, and then have it attached to your head--woven, cut, or plaited--and made to look like your own.

Jenifa now requires a loan to purchase additional supplies of haircare products and accessories. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of haircare products and accessories

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 37 year old Fatuma J.. She is single with two children, ages 16 and 21.

In 1997, Fatuma established a printing and stationary business. She now requires a loan to purchase printer cartridges and paper. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional printer cartridges and paper.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 42 year old Mariam M.. She is single with one child, age nine.

In 2000, Mariam established a poultry business. She now requires a loan to purchase additional chicks to raise and sell. She thanks you for your support.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. In fact, if you are a regular lender on kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku. Who or what are kuku, you may ask. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons.

Firstly, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two and then either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiple naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. I’m sure there are hundreds of other reasons why raising kuku is so popular--maybe they are friendlier than other animals or prettier--but this is all time and space will allow.

loans.use: To purchase additional chicks to raise and sell.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 26 year old Patricia K.. She is single and has no children.

In 2005, Patricia established a hardware business. She now requires a loan to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her hardware store

loans.name: Mwanate

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 31 year old Mwanate A.. She is single with one child, age eight, and has one other dependent who lives with her because she is an orphan.

In 2007, Mwanate established a grocery store business. Working seven days a week for 13 to 16 hours a day and assisted by her children, she earns about $60.00 per month from this business. Mwanate now requires a loan to purchase additional stock in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $65.00. In the future, Mwanate also plans to open another business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of rice, oil, and water in bulk

loans.name: Tupilike

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 52 year old Tupilike M.. She is single with two children, and has two other dependents who live with her because they are orphans.

In 2005, Tupilike established a stationary business. She works six days a week and is assisted by one employee. Tupilike has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a loan to purchase additional stock of paper and printing cartridges. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase printing cartridges and paper

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 39 year old Martha K.. She is single with four children, between the ages of 9 and 25.

In 2001, Martha established a charcoal and small retail business. Working seven days a week for nine to twelve hours a day and assisted by her children, she earns about $225.00 per month from this business. Martha now requires a loan to purchase additional stock in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $170.00. In the future, Martha also plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

Note that these small, black, and dirty pieces of dry earth are important not just to charcoal sellers but to their customers, who rely on charcoal to cook their meals. Many Tanzanians still use small coal pots, in which they arrange mkaa (charcoal) and add either paper, dry grass, old plastic bags, or kerosene to light them. The fire requires constant fanning to ignite and maintain the flame, and makes cooking quite a hot and laborious task.
